IndependentScientists have uncovered a new species of dinosaur during studies in Neuquen, central ArgentinaPalaeontologists have unearthed the remains of a previously unknown species of dinosaur that lived 110 million years ago in Argentina.The remains of three separate members of the new species, an adult and two juveniles, were discovered by a team of Spanish and Argentinian scientists at a site in Neuquen in the centre of the South American country.The new species, named Lavocatisaurus agrioensi, is a member of the herbivourous group of dinosaurs known as sauropods, which includes the likes of the diplodocus and brontosaurus.Birds got their colourful eggs from dinosaur ancestors, study suggestsLargest dinosaur foot ever recorded came from brachiosaur, study findsDinosaurs are much weirder than we ever thoughtScientists said remains that belonged to the adult suggested it would have been around 12 metres in length, while both the young discovered were between six and seven metres long.“We found most of the cranial bones: the snout, the jaws, a lot of teeth, also the bones that define the eye sockets for example and, in that way, we were able to create an almost complete reconstruction,” Jose Luis Carballido, a researcher at the Egidio Feruglio museum told Agence France-Presse.“Not only is this the discovery of a new species in an area where you wouldn't expect to find fossils, but the skull is almost complete.”Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A Salvadorean migrant with a girl He acquitted himself well, however, in a film that largely conformed to genre formula but offered strength in depth with Dan Aykroyd, Viola Davis, Lennie James and Octavia Spencer among the supporting cast.510 6. What’s Love Got to Do with It? (1993)Angela Bassett and Laurence Fishburne were superbly matched as Tina and Ike Turner in Brian Gibson’s unflinching account of their rise to fame and abusive marriage. While F Gary Gray's film lost its way in its second half, becoming bogged down in contract disputes, overall it did a superb job of capturing the vitality and righteous anger of the album of the same name. O'Shea Jackson Jr's performance as his own real-life father, Ice Cube, was a revelation.Jamie Foxx was ideally cast as Ray Charles in Taylor Hackford’s telling of the life of the blind soul star, charting his rise from poverty in rural Florida to worldwide acclaim. A sample of Foxx singing “I Got a Woman” provided the unlikely basis for Kanye West’s huge hit “Gold Digger” in 2005.810 3. issueClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May&nbsphas reportedly&nbspsecured concessions from Brussels to keep the whole of the UK in a customs union in the wake of&nbspBritain’s withdrawal from the&nbspEuropean Union.&nbspThe agreement reached would&nbspprevent the need for&nbspNorthern Ireland&nbspto be treated differently from the rest of the UK, a main stumbling block during&nbspBrexit&nbspnegotiations.The “secret”&nbspdeal would avoid&nbspthe need for an Irish backstop and&nbspwill be written into the legally-binding&nbspdeal, according to The Sunday Times.&nbspHowever, Downing Street has poured cold water on the report, calling it speculation.More than 70 business leaders back final say Brexit referendumEU slavery victims at risk of re-exploitation after BrexitBBC defends booking Brexit donor Arron Banks for Andrew Marr Brexit is putting Good Friday Agreement at risk, Varadkar saysMore Britons expected to travel abroad next year, despite BrexitThe EU has reportedly suggested a backstop post-Brexit customs arrangement covering all of the UK could give mainland Britain some scope to set trade rules.Preparations for a final deal were far more advanced than previously disclosed, the report said, and would lead to a document of 50 pages or more being published.The agreement would include an “exit clause” designed to convince Brexit-supporting MPs&nbspthat remaining in the customs union was only temporary, The Sunday Times&nbspsaid.Ms May’s cabinet would meet on Tuesday to discuss her plan, and she hoped&nbspthere would be enough progress by Friday for the EU to announce a special summit, the newspaper reported.The prime minister’s office has described the report as speculation, but claimed the majority of a deal on Britain’s exit from the bloc in March 2019 had been agreed.“This is all speculation,” a spokesman for Ms May said. “The prime minister has been clear that we are making good progress on the future relationship and 95 percent of the withdrawal agreement is now settled and negotiations are ongoing.”Meanwhile, more than 70 business figures are calling for a public vote on the final terms of Britain’s exit from the European Union, warning that the country faces “either a blindfold or a destructive hard Brexit”, the newspaper also reported.Firms are increasingly concerned about the prospect of Britain crashing out of the EU without an agreement, or that politicians will sign up to a deal that limits companies’ access to the continent’s markets.A new group called “Business for a People’s Vote”, which includes Justin King, former boss of the Sainsbury’s supermarket chain, and John Neill, head of the car parts supplier Unipart, is to be launched as campaigners raise the pressure on politicians.“We are now facing either a blindfold or a destructive hard Brexit. Both these options will further depress investment,” the letter says.“They will be bad for business and bad for working people. Given that neither was on the ballot in 2016, we believe the ultimate choice should be handed back to the public with a People’s Vote.”The government’s Brexit department said it was confident of securing a deal that works for businesses and reiterated its opposition to a second referendum.“The people of the United Kingdom have already had their say in one of the biggest democratic exercises this country has ever seen and the prime minister has made it clear that there is not going to be a second referendum,” a spokesman said.Additional reporting by ReutersThe Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: brexit latest no deal irish border article 50
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspAs a compromise on the Irish border edges&nbspcloser, Europe Correspondent Jon Stone looks at what happens nextClick to followIndy PoliticsTailbacks: a vision of a no-deal Brexit? There may yet be a Brexit agreement on the Irish border. The latest whispers out of meetings in Brussels are that the EU is preparing to offer a compromise solution on the so-called “backstop”. Whether it will be enough for the UK remains to be seen.But let’s suppose it is, and a withdrawal agreement is signed. Does that prevent a no deal? Not exactly.There are two things that could still cause a no-deal Brexit. Both bring a huge degree of uncertainty.EU plans compromise on customs union to solve Irish borderThe first is the parliamentary vote. Theresa May, you may remember, has no majority in the House of Commons and needs help. How the DUP, Labour, and Conservative Eurosceptics&nbspvote will determine whether a deal passes parliament, even if it has been agreed between&nbspnegotiators.The second uncertainty is over the future trading relationship. An outline of this was supposed to have been agreed by now, but the timetable has slipped because of a lack of progress on Northern Ireland, which the EU insists must be dealt with first.&nbspIt is not widely understood that UK law states that this outline of the future relationship has to be presented to MPs before any vote on the withdrawal deal. But it is simply not clear how this will be possible.&nbspTheresa May’s Chequers plan has been dismissed, and she has rejected the EU’s options of a loose free trade agreement or Norway-style single market participation. Negotiations are practically at square one for this, with practically no time left.It is widely claimed that any document will have to be a fudge. But the EU said at the Salzburg summit that any outline must be specific – not just a list of vague aspirations.Brexit talks ‘close to a deal’ says DUP leader Arlene FosterGovernment urged to revive fishing for endangered tuna after BrexitArron Banks is hoping to become some kind of Brexit martyrUK construction dogged by Brexit uncertainty in OctoberHow agreement could be reached on anything substantial is unclear, and neither side looks able to back the other’s proposals. It’s possible the issue of the trading relationship could make a comeback and sink the whole thing.And yet, if we cannot sign a deal, Britain may still avoid heading over the cliff edge.&nbspThe government says emphatically it is prepared to go ahead with a no-deal Brexit, but the truth is the country is simply not prepared. The physical infrastructure needed is not in place and will take years to build, at ports, airports, and elsewhere.&nbspThere is certainly not a majority in the House of Commons for a no-deal, and the political damage to the government of going ahead with one far outweighs any benefit.However, there remains the option to revoke Article 50 – even temporarily – before March 29.&nbspEmpty supermarket shelves, grounded flights, and queues at ports are a prime minister’s worst nightmare. But the wider market reaction was more muted.“The US released the strongest employment report in over a decade today,” said Eric Norland of CME&nbspGroup.“These numbers should underpin both strong consumer spending as well as generate inflation fears.&nbspMoreover, the exceptionally strong employment numbers will give the Federal Reserve the ammunition that it needs to continue raising rates, despite objections from the White House.”&nbspThe US central bank raised interest rates to 1.75-2 per cent in September to cool what it sees as rising inflationary pressures.Projections by Fed’s policymakers signal&nbspone further quarter point rate hike later this year, followed by three in 2019 and another three in 2020.The BLS&nbspsaid the major October jobs gains were in healthcare (36,000), manufacturing (32,000), construction (30,000) and transportation (25,000).Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - It will serve as an opportunity for businesses to reach people, he said.WhatsApp update finally brings stickers to messaging appThe status feature is something like the stories tool that appears in Instagram and Facebook, as well as WhatsApp. It allows people to post updates that will appear to all of their friends, letting them share photos or text and then letting it disappear afterwards.WhatsApp has struggled to come up with ways to show its users ads: without a feed, like Instagram or Facebook, there are few places for them to be injected.When it dropped its subscription fee in 2016, the company posted a blog post making clear that ads would never interrupt your communication, further adding to the issues about how advertising could be shown within the app.But the status feature appears to have solved that problem, allowing WhatsApp to slide marketing posts in between updates from friends, like it does with Instagram stories.As well as serving as something like a feed, WhatsApp's status feature has quickly become a huge part of the app. It now has a huge number of users, and is more popular than many major apps like Snapchat.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Paris struck a deal with the Republic of Ireland to fast-track its commercial drivers crossing the Channel from Dover to the French port.The agreement was made between Ireland&rsquos Foreign Minister Simon Coveney and his French counterpart Jean-Yves Le Drian on Wednesday.Mr Coveney said: &ldquoWe&rsquove had quite detailed discussions in terms of differentiating Irish trucks from British trucks. Under the right circumstances Irish trucks will not need to be inspected, whereas UK trucks may need to be inspected.But the deal has angered haulage firms in the UK, who have blasted the EU for an apparent attempt to punish and humiliate Britain over Brexit.                BREXIT BOMBSHELL: May will ask Cabinet to sign deal or QUIT on TUESDAY                Claims of Brexit deal on banking quashed by No10Brexiteers were also doubtful the deal would work.Richard Burnett, head of the Road Haulage Association, said: &ldquoThis seems completely impractical to me, and is full of potential flaws. It appears ill-thought through.Dover MP Charlie Elphicke added: &ldquoIt beggars belief that the Irish think they can have special access through Dover just because the French say so.Former first minister of Northern Ireland Lord Trimble also waded into the row and accused the Irish government of using Brexit negotiations as leverage to undermine the Good Friday Agreement.The agreement was made between Ireland&rsquos Foreign Minister Simon Coveney and his French counterpart (Image: )Paris struck a deal with the Republic of Ireland to fast-track its commercial drivers (Image: )Lord Trimble, who won the Nobel prize for his part in the peace process, accused Leo Varadkar of &ldquoriding roughshod over the 1998 agreement.He also claimed that Brexit could result in Northern Ireland ending up as part of an &ldquoeffective EU protectorate.The news came after it emerged last night that Mrs May had given the nod to a fresh Brexit proposal she will present to Cabinet ministers next week in what some have called a fresh &ldquostitch up.The plan is said to be a potential end to the Northern Ireland border riddle that has plagued Brexit negotiations since they began more than two years ago.                Brexit news: EU preparing Irish backstop concessions for Theresa May                EU nations DEMAND access to British waters for soft Ireland border The new proposal would see the UK as a whole enter into a &ldquobare bones customs union with the EU until a future trade deal is negotiated.But this would still see Northern Ireland shackled to EU rules and regulations, creating the ide down the Irish Sea that Mrs May has since been trying to avoid.The deal is being ironed out by Mrs May&rsquos EU advisor Olly Robbins.Meanwhile, both No 10 and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier denied a deal on financial services has been agreed on after the pound plunged by one percent due to the rumour.

story: A former EU judge accused the EU of being &ldquoinflexible over Brexit and believes they &ldquodo not set out the principal problems of the Irish border issue.Speaking to BBC, Professor Franklin Dehousse said: &ldquoYou see that there was flexibility and the question is, why has this flexibility completely disappeared now.&ldquoI suggest to many people on the EU side that they think very carefully about the political context they could create.Discussing whether the EU is trying to be flexible over changes made to the text of the Irish backstop, the International Law and Economics Professor said: &ldquoFirst I haven&rsquot seen the text but I read a lot of comments, they are trying to be flexible but they do not set out the principle problems. principles&rsquo for what the future access relationship might be for UK-based banks and other financial institutions to the EU's single market.However, ITV&rsquos Robert Peston said it wasn&rsquot all good news for Britain because the nation is still a &ldquomillion miles from a deal and the agreement would see London become the &ldquorule-taker.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab also arrived in title: Brexit news UK Theresa May European Union Australia EU latest deal
story: Alexander Downer, Chairman Policy Exchange, has urged the Prime Minister to stand by her &ldquono deal is better than a bad deal stance as the final stages of Brexit negotiations near.Theresa May is sticking by her controversial Chequers blueprint, despite criticism from EU leaders and prominent Leave supporters in her own party.Speaking to Express, Australia&rsquos former Foreign Minister urged Mrs May to &ldquobe tough in the final moments of talks with Brussels.He said: &ldquoMy advice to her would be to be very tough with the European Union, and not to shy away from the position she has always taken, which is &lsquono deal is better than a bad deal&rsquo.                TRUTH AT LAST: Varadkar feud with rival REAL reason for Brexit delay                NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What could no-deal mean for your medication?&ldquoIf you say actually that&rsquos not right, &lsquono deal is worse than a bad deal&rsquo, what actually that&nbspmeans&nbspis&nbspyou should sign up to whatever the European Union wants, and I have described that.&ldquoThey are completely rational in wanting that, I am not&nbspcriticising&nbspthem for wanting that.&ldquoSo she needs to hang tough and make it perfectly clear, in particular, that she is going to stick with her view that that UK will no longer remain in the customs union, or you won&rsquot be able to gain any economic advantage after leaving the EU.The Irish border remains a major sticking point in exit negotiations with the Prime Minister rejecting the European Union&rsquos proposed backstop.Theresa&nbspMay said that no British Prime Minister could accept the European Union&rsquos so-called backstop, which would effectively see a border implemented down the middle of the Irish Sea.Mr&nbspDowner, who also served as Australia&rsquos High Commissioner to the United Kingdom from 2014 to 2018, claimed the Irish border issue was the EU&rsquos problem and told the Prime Minister to reiterate that to the Brussels bloc in negotiations.He said: &ldquoShe needs to remain really tough on one specific issue, which is the Irish border issue.&ldquoRemember, and I don&rsquot think people have focused on this, if the UK leaves the EU without an agreement, the result will be a hard border with Ireland. People have got to remember that.Brexit news: Alexander Downer urged the Prime Minister to remain strong in Brexit negotiations (Image: EXPRESS&bull)&ldquoThe EU actually doesn&rsquot have&nbspmuch negotiating&nbspclout on this issue and yet they have somehow scared people in the UK into believing it&rsquos the UK's responsibility to fix this problem. On the&nbspcontrary,&nbspit is the EU&rsquos responsibility to fix this problem.&ldquoThe UK has said they will not establish a hard border along the Irish border, only the EU has said it will do that.&nbspWell,&nbspthat is a matter for Ireland and the EU. It would be a huge shame if they decided to do it, and&nbsppersonally,&nbspI think it would be quite wrong for them to do that, but if that&rsquos what they want to do. It&rsquos a free world in the EU, they can do what they like.&ldquoTheresa May needs to make this clear. What country is going to lose the most from a failed negotiation? It&rsquos Ireland, not the UK, it&rsquos Ireland.Mr&nbspDowner claimed the European Union&rsquos best Brexit outcome would be to keep Britain tied to the single market and customs union without voting power.The former Australian warned that prospect would be an &ldquoabsolutely hopeless outcome for Britain before adding he thought a &ldquocompromise would be agreed in negotiations.In a letter released to MPs revealed this week, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab suggested an agreement about the UK's departure from the European bloc would be&nbspfinalised&nbspbefore November 21.The EU Brexit secretary said: The end is now firmly in sight and, while obstacles remain, it cannot be beyond us to navigate them.But, officials insisted that many issues still need to be resolved before an agreement between the UK and EU is secured.Speaking during a meeting in Oslo on Tuesday,&nbspMrs&nbspMay told leaders of countries including Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Denmark, Finland, Iceland and Sweden she was looking to secure a good Brexit deal with the EU after Brexit.She said: Yes the UK is leaving the EU, we are not leaving Europe, and we will continue to have, we want to continue to have, a good relationship with the 27 countries remaining in the EU.

story: Residents in Sunderland voted in favour of Brexit by a majority of 61 percent during the 2016 referendum, and some locals have now become frustrated with the speed of withdrawal.One man said he was convinced leaving the European Union would be a simple matter to ensure Britain returned to be Great Britain.Speaking to RTE, the thwarted Leave voter said: I thought it would be a simple matter of leaving, sorting out the trade deal and then getting on with our lives.Be Great Britain again. Great Britain again.                Nick Ferrari SHUTS DOWN Lord Adonis for labeling Brexit 'FAILED'Another Sunderland resident admitted voters did not know what leaving the bloc would effectively mean but she resolutely demanded Theresa May get it done as quickly as possible.She said: We didn&rsquot know what it all involved at the time, I don&rsquot think. I think now we just need to get it done.Despite increased attempts to force the British Government into agreeing to a second Brexit referendum, Leave supporters have come out in hordes to clamp out attempts to keep Britain in the European Union.Ronald Mitchell launched a petition on the UK Government&rsquos website demanding &ldquodemocratic rules are respected after 700,000 Britons marched on the streets of London calling for a second Brexit vote.Brexit news: Sunderland voters demanded Theresa May get it done with the negotiations (Image: RTE&bullPARLIAMENT TV)The petition, which at the time of writing has been signed by 110,429 people, said: &ldquoAlthough not legally binding the referendum on whether we stay or leave the EU carried out on the 23rd June 2016 was the clearest indicator of the will of the electorate.&ldquoAt that time our Prime Minister David Cameron assured us that the result of the referendum would be carried out.&ldquoWe must ensure democracy rules.Breaching the 100,000 threshold does not automatically mean a debate will take place but it does force Parliament to consider a debate. What you gonna do?&ldquoWhat you gonna do, Jeremy Hunt? What you gonna do, Dominic Raab? Sajid Javid? Gavin Williamson? Geoffrey Cox? I know you don&rsquot like it. Are you really really gonna walk out of this cabinet and say that you&rsquod prefer no deal?&rsquo&ldquoWe might suddenly find ourselves in that moment.

title: dog food safety pet food raw sugar substitute sweetener xylitol foods to avoid dog owner
story: Kate Chacksfield gave a tragic account of the moment her dog Ruby died after eating homemade brownies which contained sugar substitute xylitol.Ms Chacksfield suffers from M.E. and had been replacing sugar in her cooking with the artificial sweetener, which can be lethal to dogs.She told LBC: &ldquoI was told when I was trying to get better, having been ill for years, that I should get rid of sugar and replace it in your cooking with these great products xylitol and stevia leaf.&ldquoNow, xylitol is wonderful for humans in that respect and I have no problem with the product. But I didn&rsquot know that it was lethal to dogs and so many people just don&rsquot know.                Diabetes type 2 - five &lsquohealthy&rsquo snack swaps for blood sugarDespite the brownies being put into a pot and on a high shelf, Ruby, a Hungarian vizsla, found and ate two of the large treats.Ms Chacksfield added: &ldquoI didn&rsquot really think much of it because she has eaten brownies before and it had never affected her before so I just sort of half kept an eye. I didn&rsquot really worry.&ldquoAnd it was only 36 hours later she began throwing up terribly and then I found her collapsed on the floor and rushed her in my arms to the vet.Ms Chacksfield said the vets &ldquodid their best but had initially treated Ruby under the impression she had consumed Warfarin, which can be used as a pest control and a substance dogs can pick up in the park.Dog food safety: Vet says one single piece of chewing gum with xylitol could prove fatal to dogs (Image: &bullLBC)As a &ldquolast ditch attempt Ruby was taken to the Royal Veterinary College but after nine days she passed away at seven years old.Ms Chacksfield said: &ldquoNine days they fought for her. They don&rsquot know why she managed to survive that long and there was always an element of hope because she wasn&rsquot at rock bottom on every scale.&ldquoIt was utterly heartbreaking. They thought she might pull through because she had some of her blood readings, her glucose readings, they were ok.Dr Nicola Robinson, a veterinary surgeon who runs the Animal Poison Line, also told LBC there are higher chances of survival if the owners act promptly.Dr Robinson added: &ldquoChewing gum represents about 70 percent of our cases about xylitol because it is so accessible in handbags and on the floor and sometimes chewed and thrown on the floor, of course, and dogs love that too.The veterinary surgeon said just one single piece of sugar-free chewing gum containing xylitol could prove fatal for dogs.

title: thirty year old student ipswich Stoke High School
story: A pupil at a secondary school in Ipswich is being investigated over claims he is 30 years old (Image: EAST ANGLIA NEWS SERVICE  SWNS)The 15-year-old male student - believed to be an asylum seeker - joined Stoke High School this year to take his GCSEs.But a fellow pupil has accused him of being 30-years-old, after the student allegedly told his classmates that he had to lie to get into the school.Posting a picture of the inidual on messaging app Snapchat, the pupil said: How's there a 30-year-old man in our maths class.The school confirmed that the student had been taken out of school and the Home Office have been alerted.                Fake child asylum seekers exposed at rate of nine per week                France cannot become &lsquoappeals court for migrants&rsquo warns Macron allyA spokesman for the school said: This is a matter for the Home Office and we have referred it to them.The student is not attending the school at this time.We can not comment further on an inidual case but we have followed Government and local authority policies and guidance, as we do for any admissions matter.Worried parents have voiced their concerns over the incident.A fellow pupil has accused him of being 30-years-old in a Snapchat post (Image: EAST ANGLIA NEWS SERVICE)One parent said: My son goes to the school and it is not a nice thought that this man is around children and sitting with them at lunch.Another parent added: This is extremely concerning.He has told students he has had to lie to go get into high school to complete his GCSEs.Ipswich MP Sandy Martin admitted he was not at all surprised the parents are upset.                Matteo Salvini accuses France of forcing child migrants back to Italy                Donald Trump sends 5,200 troops to Mexican border Mr Martin advised concerned parents not to take their children out of the school, insisting it is an extremely safe environment for children.A Home Office spokesperson said: We do not routinely comment on inidual cases.When age is disputed in immigration cases, the Home Office can order an age assessment.Social workers will assess an inidual&rsquos height, build, facial hair, voice pitch and mannerisms to determine their age.The school confirmed that the student had been taken out of school (Image: SWNS)But because age assessments are not guaranteed to be accurate, guidance states the principle of &ldquothe benefit of the doubt must be applied.According to a report published in March by the Chief Inspector of Borders and Immigration the benefit of the doubt policy was being used too readily to unaccompanied asylum seeking children.Of 618 age dispute cases resolved from July 2016 to June 2017, 65 percent of claimants were found to be over 18.

title: SA80A3 rifle british army MoD Heckler and Koch Ollie Pope
story: Two decades ago the makers upgraded the hand-held assault rifle (Image: )The SA80 was so plagued with problems since the weapon, by Heckler &amp Koch, was introduced into the British armed forces in 1987 it was given the nickname the &ldquocivil servant of guns.Two decades ago the makers upgraded the hand-held assault rifle, yet soldiers still found it was ill equipped to perform in hot and sandy locations, and even jammed on occasion when it was loaded especially in theatre in Iraq and Afghanistan.The weapon was then given an eye-watering &pound92million upgrade but it still did not do the trick, The  reports.In April however, the Ministry of Defence announced an initial &pound5.4million would be pumped into the SA80 to make sure troops &ldquohave the right equipment at the right time.                German defence &lsquoSCANDAL&rsquo just one third of new military weapons work                 Heartless gang steals &pound1,500 in donations from poppy seller, 84The new SA80 A3&rsquos enhanced accuracy, new durable hard-wearing material to improve camouflage, a lighter weight and more comfortable grip are just some of the new features of the weapon used by 5,000 soldiers.Other features include improvements to welding inside the mechanism to compensate for the small torque reaction induced by a round as it spins down the barrel, a new rail allowing for thermal imagers to be added and a semi-floating barrel which is separate from the hand guard for less vibration.As a result, the super-weapon has been added by military chiefs.Major Ollie Pope, of the Infantry Trials and Development Unit (ITDU), said: &ldquoIt is a fundamentally different weapon today.The SA80&rsquos improved accuracy was highlighted at a recent international military tournament (Image: )&ldquoWe have a more accurate, more lethal weapon than almost anyone else out there.The SA80&rsquos improved accuracy was highlighted at a recent international military showing tournament in Canada when British solders that completed flew home with armfuls of awards.A spokesman for Heckler &amp Koch said: &ldquoThere was concern the bad guys were getting too close before the 5.56mm runs could take them out.Before the successful upgrade, each rifle would have been adjusted, or &lsquozeroed&rsquo in military jargon, to the inidual firer, which meant constantly removing the sight resulting in losing the zero and inaccurate firing.Lieutenant Colonel Nick Serle, Commanding Officer of the ITDU, said user feedback had been positive, with further improvements to weapons and equipment planned.                World War 3: China sending UNDERCOVER students to West                 Army veteran targeted by thieves as he sold Remembrance Day poppiesHe said: &ldquoWe are continually trying to reduce the weight and cognitive burdens on the soldier.The Ministry of Defence said the SA80 A3 will remain in service beyond 2025.

title: BBC Weather London UK latest Met Office weather forecast winter cold
story: BBC Weather forecaster Ben Rich said temperatures will hit the high teens on Sunday as mild southerly winds push out the freezing temperatures.He said: &ldquoFrost is not a word I will be using at all in this week ahead forecast. I do have some wind and some rain for you, though.My Rich referenced an area of low pressure during the BBC&rsquos long-range forecast on Friday and said: &ldquoThis swirl of cloud was Hurricane Oscar.&ldquoIt&rsquos not a hurricane anymore but it is still a fairly deep area of low pressure and it is going to be steered to the north-west of the UK by the jet stream.                UK weather forecast: SHOCK chart shows Britain set to face FREEZE                UK weather forecast: Yellow weather WARNING in force - travel chaos&ldquoThat will mean that it&rsquoll be northern and western areas that see the wettest and windiest of the weather through the weekend.&ldquoFurther south and east you are, on the other side of the jet stream, a better chance that you will stay dry and see some sunshine.The BBC host also warned the wind speed on Saturday afternoon could reach as high as 60 miles per hour across the western side of Scotland.The southerly winds will bring with them some milder air, with temperatures generally 15C and parts of north-east Scotland expected to hit 17C.BBC Weather: Temperatures set to reach 17C in London (Image: Met Office)Into Saturday evening when bonfire celebrations are expected to begin, Mr Rich said: &ldquoStill some outbreaks of rain for some western and central areas &ndash particularly Cardiff could see some rain for any fireworks displays, for example.&ldquoIt will be quite windy but it will stay pretty mild. And as we go into the second half of the weekend low pressure will still be dominating the scene, moving to north-west and this will leave us with mild southwesterly winds adds still our weather front moving slowly and still, at this stage, likely to be bringing some rain across parts of the&nbspsouth west, fringing into Wales and the West Midlands.&ldquoIn fact, turning very wet across the south west of England later in the day.The BBC Weather presenter said it will &ldquostill be relatively mild on Sunday night and into Monday morning.Mr Rich said temperatures could continue to heat up on Monday, adding: &ldquoIt does look like low pressure will, again, be sitting generally to the western side of the UK. And at this stage, if the wind direction is just right, eastern areas could get into some very mild air indeed.The BBC host said it would hit 17C in London on Monday and into double figures &ldquoeverywhere you look.But the weather could take a U-turn on Tuesday as another area of low pressure approaches Britain once again and unleashes heavy rainfall and strong winds.&nbspHe said: &ldquoAs we head towards the end of the week the jet stream will still for a time be keeping weather systems to the western side of the UK.&ldquoBut there is a chance that as we get towards next weekend the jet stream might break through a little bit more and allow weather systems to slide a bit further east so bringing some rain a bit further east.&ldquoIf that happens we could start to tap into some cooler air. But actually it looks on balance like it will stay with a mild feel.Mr Rich added: &ldquoGenerally speaking, the chill is over &ndash&nbspfor now.The Met Office also said the jet stream will trigger a heat up in temperatures i Britain over the weekend. The Met Office forecast reads: &ldquoThe jet stream lies across the UK this weekend, bringing unsettled weather to many of us.&ldquoThis will also bring mildewing air across the UK from the south.&ldquoThe jet stream will continue to draw mild air from the south into mid-week.

title: Macron Merkel EU European Project Germany France Italy eurozone
story: Angela Merkel stunned the political world this week by announcing that she would stand down as CDU party leader at the end of this year.The embattled German Chancellor also said that he would not run again for a fifth term as the country's leader at the 2021 national elections.The loss of Mrs Merkel is a huge blow to French President Emmanuel Macron, whose grand plans for EU reform are all but dead, according to leading European experts.Mr Macron is an avowed pro-European with plans to defeat the populist wave across the continent and bring the EU closer together.&nbsp                Angela Merkel successor MUST make up for her huge EU mistakes                UN migration plan collapsing as Poland is FIFTH country to REJECT pactMrs Merkel's successor is likely to distance themselves from eurozone integration and big reform plans, which could spell disaster for Mr Macron.Germany, largely seen as the engine of Europe, has been a leader on the EU agenda, particularly with Brexit and tensions between the new Italian government and Brussels.Gregory Viscusi, from Bloomberg News, told France24: The two men in the lead as a potential successor to Merkel are&nbspmuch less keen on deeper European integration than she was.It doesn&rsquot look good for Macron. He came to power with a grand bargain that he would reform France and modernise its economy in exchange that Germany would accept deeper eurozone integration.The loss of Mrs Merkel is a huge blow to French President Emmanuel Macron (Image: )With the elections in Italy and with these changes in Germany, nothing will happen on that front. Macron is the last man standing.Portguese reporter&nbspAna Navarro Pedro added: Macron has lost a lot of his shine in Europe. The EU capitals used to see him as the white knight of Europe.He has been belligerent towards nationalists in Europe. He has this eitheror approach that does not create stability or certainty.Whether you liked her or not, Merkel meant stability, something steady. Macron will not be able to pick up the flag form Merkel.Josef Janning of the European Council on Foreign Relations described Mrs Merkel as a&nbspvery lame duck until a new party leader is elected, without carte blanche to move in Europe.He added: 2018 was&nbspsupposed to be the year of reform.&nbspBut nothing much has happened except trying to solve one crisis after another.Alain Lamassoure, a French centre-right MEP, said: For Europe this is not good new.&nbspThe risk is that for the rest of the German parliamentary term we have a Germany that is more or less paralysed.Pascal Lamy, a former European commissioner, added that Mrs Merkel had started drowning so early on in her last term in office.

title: new book reveals the best ways to keep your home safe from burglars
story: Sophie Hannah wrote A Dark Time to pass on security hints and tips to homeowners who find themselves at increased risk of burglary during the winter months.Seven homes in the UK are burgled every minute across a calendar year.A study of , homeowners carried out by a home security firm to coincide with the launch of the book found  per cent of Brits have no security measures in place whatsoever.A Dark Time is the latest entry in Hannah’s Waterhouse and Zailer series, which started in  with the release of Little Face, which sold over , copies in the UK.Sophie Hannah said: “I’ve really loved writing A Dark Time.I had an idea that Id really wanted to try out for ages – and raising awareness around the increased risks to home security now that the nights are getting darker was the perfect fit for executing it.My story idea needed exactly that setting, a dark night, and involved a burglary of a very peculiar kind – a puzzle that I knew my detectives Simon Waterhouse and Charlie Zailer would enjoy solving.UK homes are at an elevated risk of burglary thanks to the clocks going back, according to research.December was revealed as the peak time for break-ins across the UK, with  per cent of Brits experiencing a burglary in the last year alone.And six in  Brits feel more vulnerable to a break-in when the nights grow longer.However, keeping our homes warm and making sure energy bills are paid are the nation’s top concerns after the clocks go back – ahead of securing our castles.Nearly a quarter of Brits have fitted a security alarm to warn off potential intruders, and  per cent keep their house lights on to make it look like someone is home.A further  per cent close their blinds or curtains while they’re out, and just under a tenth have bought a dog to deter burglars from targeting their property.Lee Jasper, security expert at ADT said: “Year on year, we have seen a  per cent increase in burglaries during the darker months.So it’s vital that people put the right security measures in place to help protect their homes to avoid falling victim.“The research shows we’re feeling more vulnerable as a nation when the clocks go back, however there is a clear lack of awareness when it comes down to preventing burglaries.“We’re hoping that the launch of A Dark Time can help the nation safeguard their homes, in an entertaining and engaging way.”A Dark Time is available as a free download from the ADT website from Monday nd October on: https:www.adt adarktime

title: dup turn down eu compromise
story: The DUP threw up a fresh setback by insisting the Brussels blueprint would mean Northern Ireland having to accept euro judges’ orders indefinitely.The new row came as tensions ratchet again with Theresa May trying to force an agreement next week to stop the clock from running out.In an Ireland blitz, the PM despatched three Cabinet ministers to Belfast and Dublin yesterday in a bid to hammer out a border backstop deal.While Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab presses the flesh with Northern Irish politicians, Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington and Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley went to the Irish capital.Under the EU’s new plan, the whole of the UK would join a temporary “bare bones” customs union with the EU until a future trade deal is negotiated – a win for Theresa May.But while a customs border down the Irish Sea would no longer be necessary, Northern Ireland alone would still have abide by full EU rules and regulations.Throwing it out, the DUP’s Westminster leader Nigel Dodds said: “If Northern Ireland is subject to EU single market regulations, then it will also be subject to the ECJ in some form as the arbiter of those regulations.“This position leaves Northern Ireland a rule taker from Brussels.”If Theresa May sacrices their support, she and the Tories are toast.Mr Raab attempted to reassure the DUP, saying: “We’ve made it very clear we would never sign up to anything that would threaten the economic, the constitutional and let alone the territorial integrity of the United Kingdom.“We’re confident we can get a good deal, good for all four corners of the United Kingdom.”But Mr Raab again wouldn’t rule out some new regulation dferences between Ulster and the rest of the UK.After the Dublins talks Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney said a deal in November is still possible but more progress is needed and “we aren’t quite there yet”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid home office amber rudd sun says
story: His Home Office seems more dysal now even than when a large chunk of it was condemned as “not fit for purpose”  years ago.His junior minister and civil servants seem clueless about their own post-Brexit immigration policy.His predecessor Amber Rudd was given such woeful advice by two ­bungling senior officials she had to resign after repeating it.Mr Javid himself is having to be warned against the disastrous error of expanding “hate crime” to include ageism and misogyny.Britain is being engulfed by a tsunami of violence. We need a Home Secretary resolute about REAL offences — stabbings, muggings, burglaries and so on — not inventing new ones to show how liberal and erse he is.Our police chiefs HAVE had a sudden conversion to “core policing” this week. That is welcome,years too late.The Home Secretary must enforce this new focus nationwide, alongside his many other problems. Getting crime back down, reasserting law and order and fixing the shambolic Home Office could be the making of him.Mr Javid needs to shape up.THE idea that the police probe into Nigel Farage’s backer Arron Banks invalidates Brexit is a desperate stunt​ even by Remainers’ standards.They must know that Vote Leave, the official cross-party campaign, wanted nothing to do with Banks’ disruptive, self-promoting Leave.EU outfit.Nor did many voters. Which is why Leave’s support fell dramatically in polls when Leave.EU unveiled its toxic anti-migrant poster. Many waverers reluctantly opted for Remain to avoid siding with Farage and Banks. And Vote Leave still won by ,,.Imagine how much greater the margin would have been, in a nation staunchly Eurosceptic for decades, had Banks not been involved. Greater still had the Government not blown £million of our cash, outside of campaign spending, leafleting every home on Remain’s behalf.And it would be even widera second referendum was somehow brought about.To suggest that .million Leavers were swayed by dirty tricks and allegedly dodgy spending is utterly absurd.THE Government simply cannot afford to betray the DUP’s red lines on Brexit.They must not under-estimate unionist resolve. title: council smoking vaping ban staff off premises dundee
story: Dundee City Council has said it wants to reduce the number of adult role models seen with cigarettes in public and does not distinguish between fags and e-cigs.The city has some of the highest rates of smoking in the UK, while men in the city have some of the lowest le expectancy rates.Council bosses in Dundee said they want to reduce the number of adult role models seen with cigarettes in public and does not distinguish from other tobacco products of the lowest le expectancy rates.It would make them the first council in the UK to introduce the ban.The local authority plans to promote positive health messages and protect the health of employees.A stringent new policy told staff that anyone not complying would be subject to disciplinary action - includingthey smoked in the street, stepped off the premises to have a fag during a tea break, or were travelling to a dferent location.Employees would be punished eventhey were not wearing anything to identity them as council staff.The zero-tolerance policy has been greeted with dismay by Unison, which said banning e-cigs and vapes was not supporting smokers trying to give up fags.And campaign group Forest, which describes itself as the voice and friend of the smoker said the new policy was a form of bullying.Director Simon Clark said: Threatening employees with disciplinary actionthey smoke during work breaks or while theyre working out of doors, out of unorm and between locations is tantamount to bullying.Smoking is not illegal.If it doesnt interfere with their work or inconvenience colleagues, employees who wish to smoke outside during work breaks should be allowed to do so.A ban on vaping makes even less sense. Switching to e-cigarettes has helped a signicant number of smokers in their efforts to quit.If there is a genuine desire to help employees stop smoking, smokers should be encouraged to vape, not threatened with the same penalties as those caught smoking.He added: Smoking or vaping, the council is over-reaching its powers.Policing our lestyle, as long as it doesnt have a direct impact on our work or colleagues, is not the business of local government.A spokesman for Unison said: There are clear aspects of this policy we could not agree to.We are usually very supportive of anti-smoking policies.However, people who do smoke need to be able to take breaks and get support from their employer to help them give up.A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: The council has revised its smoking policy as we are working to protect the health of employees and also promote positive health messages across the wider community, in line with the agreed Our People Strategy and health and wellbeing framework.A key part of that approach involves discouraging children and young people from taking up smoking.One way to assist that is to reduce the number of adult role models who can be seen smoking in public.Across Dundee, there has been the introduction of voluntary no-smoking areas at childrens play parks and we will be looking to extend this to more open spaces in the future.

title: brexit vote maps uk reveals two countries
story: In recent months the campaign for a second referendum or so-called Peoples Vote has gathered momentum - but the nation remains as ided as it was more than two years ago.Now two fascinating maps created by mapping and analytics company Esri UK, reveal how the two Britains would lookstay or leave heartlands were cut out and replaced with lakes or sea.This is based on the results of the  EU poll.Essentially Leave Land is most of the English mainland with a hardcore in the Midlands and the North of England.  Large parts of Wales are also included.  The North East is preserved in the new Brexit nation, including Sunderland whose huge vote for Leave was the defining moment of EU referendum result night.But a large lake lies where Newcastle was because it narrowly voted for Remain. The South West and East Anglia are mostly interact.The map starkly reflects Brexiteer strongholds such as Castle Point, Essex, where . percent voted leave which was the third-highest Brexit vote of any local authority. But south of Leave Land has been eroded by huge new waterways reflecting stronger support for remain in cities.Of course London and much of the Home Counties out of the country are conspicuously missing from Leave Land.Ferries from the continent could dock in Brighton via the “Middlesex Sea” and sail up to the way to Swindon. Perhaps the layout reflects the perception among many Brexit voters that the well-off and out-of-touch elite vote Remain and they mostly live in UK capital and its surrounding areas.The highest Eemain votes in the country are . percent in Lambeth and . percent in Hackney.  But the Remainers new nation is anchored by Scotland. Here all  council areas voted to stay in the EU in the  referendum. Remain Land also includes the greater part of Northern Ireland which is has been entangled in months of negotiations over the future of the border with the Irish Republic. The largest London-based island parts of nearby counties such as Surrey, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, which also rejected Brexit.Further north remain hangs on to densely populated islands in the North West, including central Manchester.Also in Remain Land is much of the county of Merseyside, Liverpool, Wirral and Sefton which has over the years benefited from EU investment. But no all urban areas are pro-Remain. Birmingham and Sheffield the most prominent cities voted to Leave.There is the Great Britain Ocean in the West Midlands, the Sea of Humber, the Yorkshire Shallows.The North Sea Gulfmark carved out the huge chunks of land where remain was given the boot.

title: the queen played goalkeeper in kickabout with children at sandringham insider claims
story: The -year-old Monarch would often enjoy a footie match with her family in the grounds of Sandringham over the festive period.Queen Elizabeth’s love of the beautul game has been revealed in Charles at Seventy a tell-all book about Prince Charles.Royal Commentator Robert Jobson writes: “During holidays - Christmas and the New Year at Sandringham and most of the summer holidays at Balmoral - the whole family would play football, with the diminutive Queen acting as goalkeeper.”It is not clear when the Queen took her place between the sticks, but some believe it could have been in the s – when Prince Charles was a student at Cambridge.A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said: “That’s not something we’d comment on.”The royal family has enjoyed a long association with football.The Queen handed the Jules Rimet trophy to captain Bobby Moore after England’s historic World Cup win at Wembley in .While Her Royal Highness would also regularly present the FA Cup to winners.However, that duty has now been taken up by her footie-fan grandson Prince William, who is also the president of the Football Association.William is a proud Aston Villa fan, while younger brother Prince Harry supports Arsenal.Earlier this year dad-of-three William was spotted playing fiveaside with friends at a south London pitch.

title: devon man ron easton lay dying roof three days
story: Ron Easton was found in a gulley on his flat roof at his home in Bigbury-on-Sea, south Devon, on October .His neighbour raised the alarm after a build up of full milk bottles and papers at his front door.It is believed the former racing driver - known locally as Ton Up Ron - fell while attempting to fix his TV aerial.He was taken to Plymouths Derrord Hospital where his family revealed he died on Friday.Ron was a private man but earned the nickname because of his love of cars.Before his accident he would still be seen driving around in his blue MG sports car.A flag in the village has been lowered to half mast with a tribute to Ron aged -and-a-half.Louise Wainwright, editor of the local Bigbury Newsletter, said: Ron was a very private man. Its very sad.Hazel Osborne, who watched the rescue operation told PlymouthLive : Hes an incredible old boy who still drives his MG sports car. He was a rally driver who once drove in the Dakar rally.It was her friend who raised the alarm, she said: The fire service and ambulance were here. There were paramedics and first responders and then the Devon Air Ambulance arrived and you could see clouds of dust.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: why never give baby water
story: While water might seem to be perfectly harmless the smallest amount of water could affect the balance of water in a baby’s body.Giving a baby under six months old just a sip of water could overload the kidneys, leading to a dangerous condition called hyponatremia.Pharmacist Abbas Kanani told Yahoo UK: “Kidneys are also too immature in infants under six and water can cause intoxication as a result of an imbalance in electrolytes such as sodium.“This can cause hyponatraemia, which is where too much water has diluted the sodium levels of the body.“This can cause complications such as swelling of the brain, seizures and, in extreme cases, death.”Kanani added: “Giving water to an infant can affect the baby’s ability to receive adequate nourishment.“Their stomachs are so tiny and can fill up easily with water, making it dficult for them to get the nourishment they require.”Until babies are at least six months old most experts think they should only be given breast milk or formula.Katie Zeratsky, a dietitian at the Mayo Clinic, told Buzzfeed: Water intoxication is where you consume too much water in a short period of time and your blood level of sodium drops…making a tragic situation.In the adult world, you would have to push yourself past thirst and regulation to a point where you almost have to force intake.In terms of a baby, in most cases they would get too full to do this, so it would be more challenging to create this situation in an infant. It’s not impossible, though.

title: corbyn ally councils buy homes
story: Corbynista Lloyd Russell-Moyle believes town hall chiefs should be given power of first refusal on any house up for sale.And he wants to tear up planning laws to allow them to build high-rise flats in posh suburbs and leafy villages.Mr Russell-Moyle, , revealed his party will order mass compulsory purchases of former council homes sold off under the Tories’ Right To Buy scheme.But he told a Labour rally: “Let’s not just talk about council houses — let’s get those bloody private houses back into our hands.”The Brighton Kemptown MP — an ally of Jeremy Corbyn — is urging the Labour leader to take swathes of privately-owned property into public control.Left-wing activists cheered as he unveiled his plan at an anti-austerity conference under the banner “Stand With Corbyn”.Mr Russell-Moyle said a future Labour government would abolish the right to buy and “compulsory purchase en masse” sold-off housing stock.He told the London rally: “We need to develop a system that slowly over time takes property out of private hands and puts it into public hands.“For example, why not give every council the first right of refusal with any houses put up for sale “And I don’t mean a former council house — I mean your private house.”A Tory MP last night called it “pure madness”.Ex-housing minister Grant Shapps said: “The truth’s out — cuddly Corbyn wants to nationalise your home.”If voters needed any reminding of the Marxist-inspired madness that would descend after a Corbyn victory, Brighton MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle has provided it.The ‘right to buy’ revolution, letting people buy their council houses, was the bedrock of Margaret Thatcher’s premiership.It enabled millions to gain a stake in society which they could then pass on to their children.But under the powers to compulsorily purchase ex council houses, he also wants to see them get first refusal on any private homes that come on the market.Although not official Labour policy, the MP was cheered to title: foreign investors brexit liam fox opinion
story: People want to buy our world-class British products and companies want to use our services.And investors want to put their money into the UK because, like us, they know that they are investing in a country that is set to prosper as we leave the EU.New figures from the internationally respected organisation UNCTADshowed that during the first six months of , only China secured more inward investment into their country than the UK.According to the UN, China secured billion, the UK .billion and the US .billion. The Netherlands and Spain were the only other EU countries in the top ten.That is some achievement for the UK. And demonstrates that the people who know where to invest, know it should be in the UK.They know we live in a dynamic nation, brimming with potential.So as we leave the European Union, we should remember the many reasons investors choose to put their money here in the United Kingdom, which is one of the world’s largest and most successful economies.We are at record levels of employment. Our success is underpinned by a legal system whose reputation is second to none. We have a skilled workforce and a low tax and a well-regulated economy.We are home to some of the finest universities, our research and development capabilities are cutting-edge and our financial institutions world-leading.We are in the right time zone to trade with Asia in the morning and the United States in the afternoon — and, of course, we speak English, the language of global business.Plus, there is serious global momentum behind businesses in the UK. We continue to attract more Foreign Direct Investmentthan anywhere  in Europe. And we are the number one choice in Europe for key strategic investments, such as headquarters. So it’s easy to see why more than , new businesses start up here every day.And it isn’t just small and medium-sized businesses. The UK has created  of Europe’s  companies valued at more than billion.Only this week Monzo, the British bank which operates through an app on your phone, secured £million of investment in order to double its workforce. This raised the company’s value to the £billion mark just three years after its formation.This is a fantastic vote of confidence in the UK and yet another sign that we have plenty to be optimistic about after we leave the EU.Investment creates jobs across all parts of the UK, pumps money into our communities and improves the lives of millions of people.Last year, FDI created , new jobs in the UK as well as safeguarding another ,.One reason we are seeing so much success is that this government has built an environment that makes investment and job creation easy.We are champions of free trade and we actively encourage businesses of all sizes — from start-ups to large corporations — to build trading links in all corners of the world.This weekend I’ll be representing the UK at the China International Import Expo in Shanghai where we are a “country of honour”.Over recent months, China has started to open up its market for UK goods and services, including dairy products, potatoes and petrol stations.And, this weekend, we intend to build on these achievements and create even more exciting opportunities for British companies.We also possess world-class talent. For example, we excel at research and development, which means that overseas companies want to tap into British expertise to advance the quality of their products. In last week’s Budget, we announced a further £.billion to strengthen the UK’s global leadership in science and innovation — that brings the total to £billion invested in research and development since .We want a partnership with business to make our country prosper.The Government’s Industrial Strategy includes innovative deals agreed with inidual sectors to attract investment. We are already reaping the rewards.The global marketplace never slows and we, too, must never stand still.Building on our impressive investment success, I have implemented the High Potential Opportunities scheme, which will deliver growth where it is most needed, often to previously overlooked areas.The success of the AgriTech programme in the West Midlands town of Telford and Leicestershire’s leading space sector cluster are proof the benefits of global investment are being felt in every part of the country.Over recent months, the Department for International Trade has led a series of investment roundtables, promoting UK industry to a global audience and driving foreign direct-investment into the UK as we prepare to leave the European Union.So far, these events have centred on tech, le sciences, automotive and agri-tech sectors and will soon start to focus on areas such as the creative industries.Initiatives such as this are going to be key in the coming months as we develop the UK’s own independent trade policy for the first time in more than  years.Working with businesses in the UK and overseas, I am determined to continue generating this flow of good news.But the facts tell a dferent story: Confidence in Britain is riding so high around the world that foreign investors are betting on it like never before.New UN figures show that in the first six months of  we were second only to booming China in attracting investment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ghost town shops community hubs
story: Boarded-up shops will be converted into gyms, tearooms, youth clubs and advice centres to breathe new le into “ghost towns”.Ministers hope the “open doors” project will attract people back into dying city centres – and spark a mini-revival for traders.Under the plan, landlords of disused shop units will be teamed up with community groups offering key services to younger and older people.Teams of experts will help strike temporary contract deals to get the high street buzzing once again.It is hoped the move will also cut crime and tackle other urban problems such as unemployment and loneliness.That is why this week I am launching the Open Doors project to help regenerate the high street and support community groups. I recognise these challenges are linked.Our communities and our high streets will not be left behind.Communities Secretary James Brokenshire will reveal full details of when he launches a massive regeneration plan on Wednesday.More than , jobs have been lost in town centres over the past three years as the rise of internet shopping drove major retail firms to the wall.Last year alone, the high street lost a total of , shops, with major chains such as House of Fraser and BHS falling into administration and retail giants like MS closing branches.Bosses blame the rise of Amazon and other online shopping sites – whose overheads are much lower - for driving shoppers away from town centres.High Streets were given £.billion of help in last week’s Budget, including a cut in business rates for small shopkeepers, relaxation of planning laws and special funding to help transform town centres.A  of experts has been assembled to find other ways of helping town centres to survive the internet age – and carve out a new future.Their blueprint for future high streets will be published soon.Mr Brokenshire said: “I’m determined that our communities and our high streets will not be left behind.“Last week, the Budget provided a raft of measures to redevelop shops and help town centres adapt.Small retailers will see their business rates bills cut by a third, saving them up to £ million over two years.“These actions will help create a more level playing field for all retailers.”Communities Secretary James Brokenshire today tells us of his plan to regenerate town centres.But he can’t afford to be woolly or lacking in detail, and few will be convinced that a £million injection into a ‘Future High Street Fund’ will be enough to hold back the tsunami of the internet age.Good luck, Minister, but give us concrete solutions, not mealy-mouthed platitudes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate winslet labelled hero by family of gemma nuttall
story: Winslet joined grieving family and friends at the funeral of brave mum Gemma Nuttall who turned down chemotherapy to save her unborn baby’s le.Gemma, , from Rossendale, Lancashire, lost her five-year battle with oian cancer last month.Hollywood superstar Kate had stepped in to help the mum-of-one raise the funds she needed for immunotherapy and initially the treatment had been a success.But the cancer ed and the dental nurse, who leaves behind four-year-old daughter Penelope, was moved to Pendleside Hospice in Burnley earlier in October, where she passed away.Gemma’s mum Helen Sproates told : “Kate really supported my daughter and helped her.Whenever Gemma was down she’d text her and bolster her up. She’s very strong – and we needed that strength.Gemmas devastated mum Helen Sproates paid tribute to her ‘angel’ daughter saying: My world will never be the same again.She added: She would genuinely help anybodyshe could, she was just like an angel.“Kate lost her own mum to liver cancer, so for her to put that on the back burner and support us must have been really hard as she’s still grieving herself.“I know she found it hard, but she did it anyway. That’s an amazing human being who can do something like that.”Kate visited Gemma in hospital during her final days, staying at her bedside.Speaking about her relationship with little girl Penelope, Helen told The Rossendale Free Press: They were so alike, very cheeky characters, like two peas in a pod and just watching them together was just beautul. That’s not going to happen anymore.Mourners wore blue and pink at Accrington Cemetery to celebrate Gemmas le.Winslet, whose own mother was going through cancer treatment at the same time, said it was tragically sad and sent her love to Gemmas family.She told The Lancashire : It is a privilege to be able to give Gemma the send-off she deserves at the end of her incredible fight.“As a young mum Gemma’s extraordinary determination to beat her cancer for Penelope was something that deeply moved me and made me want to help.“She was so clearly a fighter. She fought her battle and against all odds she kept proving them wrong.“The fundraising had been a phenomenal success and Helen’s initial efforts to send Gemma to Germany for immunotherapy treatment hadn’t been in vain. For a while it worked.The Titanic star added: But even though that has not been the case and even though Gemma didn’t quite make it to , she did make it to Penelope’s first second, third and fourth birthdays and to her first day of big school.“They were also able to have some magical memories together which doctors thought would be impossible.“In truth Gemma lived for at least  months longer than her specialists believed. She had more time with her family.”Gemmas mother, Helen Sproates, confirmed her daughters death in a post on Facebook.The family have formed the Gemma Rose Foundation so they can help others.Ms Nuttalls mother, Ms Sproates, said: It is with an utterly broken heart that I have to tell you all that my beautul warrior lost her battle early this morning.We fought so hard but we just couldnt do it anymore – I am one very proud but devastated mum right now.Sleep tight Gemma - My world will never be the same again.She also wrote: “She was always putting others before ­herself. She was a kind and thoughtful daughter with a caring nature.“Most of all she loved her special little Penelope and was a fantastic mummy.  Penelope has been her rock and her reason to keep going as long as she did.“It is heartbreaking to know ­Penelope is now  having to grow up without her mummy’s love.”Gemma first learned she had aggressive oian cancer at her -week scan and was offered a termination so she could start le-saving treatment.But she chose to delay any treatment until after the birth of her daughter Penelope and after the birth doctors were able to remove the oian tumour.She began a gruelling round of chemotherapy while her baby battled for her le in intensive care.After initially beating the illness, Gemma said she enjoyed getting in to a routine and got a job as a trainee manager at her mum’s soft play business, Funtazia in Blackburn.But sadly, a year later, her cancer ed and after rounds of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, doctors said little could be done to save her.Gemmas mum Helen had read about immunotherapy, which boosts the bodys natural defences, available at the Hallwang Clinic in Germany.The -year-old sold her house and started a fundraising page to raise further donations to cover the cost of the huge cost of the therapy.Gemma flew to Germany last May and began a six-session course, which costs up to £, a time, but only had enough funds for the first round.In July, Helen received an email from Kate Winslets PA saying she wanted to offer her support and had contacted her Titanic co-star Leonardo Di Caprio for help.The pair auctioned themselves off for three dates at DiCaprios annual fundraising event and raised . million , which they were able to also give to other charities.Gemma got the all-clear at the start of this year and in February appeared on This Morning to revisit the amazing moment the -year-old actress offered to help pay for her treatment.Hosts Holly Willoughby and Philip Schofield then surprised the brave mum as they revealed the Hollywood star was on the other end of the phone.Winslet said: I lost my own mother last year in May to oian cancer and we as a family were given a very poor prognosis for my mum.After a four year battle... we decided to look where and we also stumbled across those places in Germany.Simultaneously I came across [Gemmas] petition campaigning to have immunotherapy made available on the NHS and my heart sunk as at that point.I thought this poor young woman is probably years away from her being able to access that kind of treatment on the national health service.I found her Go Fund Me page and I saw how much she needed to raise and at that point there was only £, in the fund and I just thought I cannot have this happen.My own mother was very, very, very unwell and I just though my mum would be very gratefulI could do this for someone , another young mum.We got close to £, and I thought, right its time to call my friend Leo.I phoned Leo and I said do you think that we could do a charity dinner or something and he said lets go one better, come with me to Saint Tropez to my benefit fundraiser and we will auction off a dinner with Jack and Rose.Gemma had viewers in tears as she told the actress: Thank you so much for all your hard work and me being able to have my treatment that I really did need. You saved my le.

title: record payouts school compensation
story: They included a youngster who tripped over a tree branch and another who got an arm trapped behind a hot radiator.Payouts were made on  compensation claims in England last year — costing taxpayers £.million.The toll was up ten per cent on £.million in , figures released under Freedom of Information laws revealed.The branch-trip pupil in St Helens, Merseyside, was paid £,.Northumberland County Council handed out £, for the radiator accident and a separate £, for a leg fracture from “a bucket swing”.In Halton, Merseyside, a pupil got £, after losing a tooth in a collision with a student during a PE lesson.A trampolining incident that left a pupil injured in Southampton led to a £, payout.And a youngster hurt tripping over a speed bump at school was paid £, by Derby County Council.While accepting that some payouts are justied, John O’Connell of the TaxPayers’ Alliance said: “Council compensation culture is costing taxpayers dear.“Every penny that goes on settlements or costlier insurance is cash that can’t be spent on essential services.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pensioners attwater iran nuclear nuts bolts
story: Paul and Iris Attwater wanted a bit of extra cash to pay for a few summer holidays and a Crawley Town FC season ticket.But Paul, , and Iris, , were hauled into court accused of helping support the Middle-Eastern country develop its nuclear weapons.Far from being shady arms dealers conducting dodgy deals, the grandparents were selling nuts and bolts to an Iraqi-born businessman in Malaysia, Alexander George, .The pair were counting out screws on the living room floor and storing aircraft parts in their loft.But investigators told them the equipment was being shipped to Iran where it could be used by the country to develop nuclear weapons.A judge called the couple “very, very naïve” and spared them jail.Paul and Iris fear they could lose their home after losing £, in their business venture and prosecutors aim to seize their assets under the Proceeds of Crime Act.Iris, a former secretary, told The Sunday People: “It’s been an absolute nightmare. We’ve been made out to be international arms dealers but nothing could be further from the truth.“It’s nothing like they were saying – it wasn’t weapons. We were literally counting , nuts and bolts on the living room floor.“We were just wanting to make a bit of money to pay for the football and go on holiday.”Paul said he thought it was a joke at first when he was interviewed and told the parts could have been going to Iran for military use.Paul pleaded guilty to being knowingly concerned in the exportation of goods with intent to evade prohibition or restriction. Iris denied the same charge but was convicted by a jury at Londons Southwark Crown Court.They were both given a six-month suspended jail sentence and barred from being company directors for six years.Judge Michael Grieve QC said the couple had been deceived by the businessman and had been naive.George, of Bristol, was found guilty of being knowingly concerned in the supply or delivery of controlled goods to an embargoed destination.He will be sentenced next month.
