title: hs2s northern extension public opposition chris grayling
story: Chris Grayling has admitted that the northern extension, connecting Birmingham to Leeds, was not in the bag - despite construction being due to start in .According to New Civil Engineer, he told a rail industry conference in London: “This industry has got to help make the case for HS. We have got to continue making that case for it.“It will be a fantastic railway, one of the best in Europe but it still needs supportit is to definitely go to Leeds and connect to the Northern Powerhouse Rail.”The first phase of HS was approved in , despite opposition from  MPs, and work is due to begin.Ale a bill for phase a - from Birmingham to Crewe - is currently going through the Commons.Legislation that will allow the line to be constructed to Manchester and Leeds is scheduled for , however Mr Graylings comments calling for support implies he fears opposition.It comes after two Cabinet ministers suggested the route should be cancelled entirely, while a third said it should be served by other forms of transport instead, the Sunday  reported.But the £billion project has been branded a game changer by ministers because many services are currently full to overflowing.The high speed rail line is expected to increase capacity on Britains railways, slash journey times and give passengers a place to sit with thousands of extra seats every day.Once complete in , the number of passengers between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds per hour could treble to ,.And there should be  commuter and intercity trains an hour between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds - a  per cent rise from the current .HS boss Sir Terry Morgan also told the conference last month: I absolutely do think that we still have a selling case to do for HS.“The truth is, that without the northern section of HS there isn’t a business case for the line at all.“You wouldn’t do HS on the basis of Phase  [London to Birmingham] on its own. HS definitely needs Phase , otherwise it does not work.”

title: brexit is undermining peace in northern ireland
story: The Irish prime minister gave a stark warning about the state of cross-border relations on Saturday, with just months to go before the UK is due to quit the European Union.His comments came after another Dublin politician said ato a hard border threatened the peace process, in a row following reports that a backstop plan was close to being agreed with Brussels.Senator Neale Richmond, who chairs the Seanads Brexit Committee, told Brexiteer Tory MP Owen Paterson on BBC Radio s Today programme that plans for solving the border dispute using existing practical systems was completely unfeasible.Speaking on RTE Radio Ones Marian Finucane programme on Saturday morning, the Taoiseach said: Brexit has undermined the Good Friday Agreement and it is fraying relationships between Britain and Ireland.Anything that pulls the two communities apart in Northern Ireland undermines the Good Friday Agreement and anything that pulls Britain and Ireland apart undermines that relationship.His comments came two days after Nobel peace prize winner and Conservative Lord Trimble accused Mr Varadkars government of riding roughshod over the  agreement.Lord Trimble, who helped draw up the landmark agreement which ended decades of deadly fighting in the province, claimed that the Brexit process could result in Northern Ireland ending up as part of an effective EU protectorate.Brexit talks have reached an impasse over the EUs backstop plan, which would see Northern Ireland effectively remaining in the customs union and single market unless alternative arrangements were found to prevent a hard border.But reports from Dublin had suggested that a deal involving an all-UK customs union in the Withdrawal Agreement, plus a separate backstop for Northern Ireland, is close to being agreed.On Friday, Irelands deputy premier, Simon Coveney, said he believed a Brexit deal could be reached by the end of November, with his Westminster counterpart, Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington, saying negotiators were very close, after the pair held talks in Dublin.

story: But I would give up all the recognition and accolades in a flash just to see my daughter again - it will be  years ago next March that I last saw her.Claudia went missing on her way to work as a chef at the University of York. title: brexit tycoon arron banks insists
story: NewsBrexit tycoon Arron Banks insists probe over £m campaign funds is politically motivatedThe millionaire argued a watchdog investigation into his funding was triggered by RemainersShareCommentsByAlan Selby:,  NOV NewsMillionaire Arron Banks has spoken out against the probe "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailArron Banks Banks yesterday insisted the probe he faces over his poundmillion Brexit campaign funds is “politically motivated”. Mr Banks, , is being investigated for suspected criminal offences regarding campaign funding during the referendum. The National Crime Agency probe was launched this week after the Electoral Commission said it had reasonable grounds to suspect Mr Banks was not the true source of the cash.  He supported fellow Leave campaigner and business associate Liz Bilney, who has also been referred to the NCA. Mr Banks said none of the funds borrowed by the Leave campaign came from Russia. He said: “The money just hasn’t come from Russia. The money came from me. We’re going to co-operate with the NCA and they’ll have visibility into our accounts... We don’t have any connections with Russia. We don’t do business in Russia.” At Gatwick airport yesterday, he insisted the probe was triggered by Remainers, as he stepped off a flight from Bermuda after a fishing trip.  He said: “It’s politically motivated. There’s a cabal of MPs, along with the fake news committee. There’s a range of people. The Electoral Commission have already been called, by a judge, not fit for purpose – they’ve made their own views plain. “The chairman called it a collection of Eurosceptic nonsense. Of course it’s politically motivated.” The Electoral Commission’s review focused on poundmillion reported to have been loaned to Better for the Country by Mr Banks and his insurance companies, and a poundmillion donation he made alone. It also said loans involved a company, Rock Holdings, based on the Isle of Man, which was impermissible under the rules.

story: NewsAlmost two thirds of top firms fail to pay “real living wage” while their bosses earn millions a yearThe  biggest companies raked in a combined £.billion profit last yearShareCommentsByStephen Hayward:,  NOV NewsTop earners include Persimmon house builder boss Jeff Fairburn, paid £million last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNearly two thirds of top UK firms fail to pay the “real living wage” while their bosses earn millions a year. The  biggest companies raked in a combined pound.billion profit last year. And some chief executives banked  times more than the average pay of their full time workers. Top earners include Persimmon house builder boss Jeff Fairburn, paid poundmillion last year, and chief executive of business specialist Melrose, Simon Peckham, on a pound.million package. The huge pay gap has been revealed by the High Pay Centre think tank.  It looked at the top  firms on the London Stock Exchange ahead of Living Wage Week, starting tomorrow. The Government’s legal minimum is pound. an hour but the real living wage is pound.. Around a third of FTSE  firms are accredited to the Living Wage Foundation, which recommends the higher figure.  The figures are likely to spark fresh calls for a government cap. The High Pay Centre said: “Pay is not just a business issue but a moral one, companies need to recognise the message figures send about their values.”

title: archaeologists dig up 60000 ancient
story: NewsArchaeologists dig up , ancient skeletons buried near Londons Euston Station in -year old cemeterySt James Gardens, the resting place of several historic figures, is being excavated to make way for the new HS high-speed rail link despite campaigns against the plansShareCommentsByHana Carter:,  NOV NewsCaptain Matthew Flinders was buried in the site "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWork to dig up , skeletons near London Euston has begun, despite campaigners battling to leave the bodies in peace. The -year-old burial ground at St James Gardens is being excavated by a team of more than  archaeologists as part of the HS high-speed rail project. Coffins containing the bones of people laid to rest from  to , with some belonging to influential people in history. Captain Matthew Flinders, one of Britains most prolic explorers, known for being responsible for navigating and naming Australia was buried in the graveyard.  Bill Richmond, the first black boxer to reach international recognition, who travelled from America to England in  was laid to rest in the Camden plot. Lord George Gordon, who in  called for the repeal of the Catholic Relief Act and ato the repression of Catholics. So far, archaeologists have uncovered the bones of , people from the former th and th-century burial ground in what has been branded Britains largest archaeological exploration. Similar digs along the -mile HS route have unearthed Victorian time capsules, Neolithic tools and medieval pottery. The route will explore treasure troves full of prehistoric, roman and world war relics.  The dig in Camden will add to our understanding of how this city transformed, HS officials said. Originally the work was furiously rejected by campaigners in Camden who branded the work to expand Euston station as outrageous. Dorothea Hackman, a local churchwarden who helped to organise the private memorial service, said  people are being allowed to gather at the now-closed St James Gardens to pay respect to the people buried there.  Its quite outrageous they are going to dig up our dead, she said. They shouldnt be disturbed by spurious activities like this. Campaigners have also protested that a memorial service should be held to honor the disturbed dead. As well as upset over the exhumation of the bodies, trees will also be removed to make way for the high-speed rail line.  Anne Stevens, the vicar of neighbouring St Pancras Church, chained herself to one of the trees in January. In retaliation, an HS spokesman said: Though the former burial ground at St James Gardens has not been in use for more than  years, we will ensure that we treat the site with dignity, respect and care. Bosses at HS are working with Historic England, the Church of England and the local parish to plan the reburial of the remains. This is not the first time that the dead have been disturbed at St James Gardens. In August  the burial ground was transformed into public gardens. Then in the late th century a quarter of graves were partly or entirely removed for work on Euston station.

title: brave woman reveals how brought
story: NewsBrave woman reveals how she brought rapist dad to justice after chance meeting following sisters deathEXCLUSIVE: Caryn Walker has told the sisters’ horric story - including trying to barricade her bedroom door - in a heartbreaking memoir entitled Tell Me You’re Sorry, DaddyShareByGeraldine McKelvie:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCaryn Walker was abused by her dad for eight years "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery night, little Caryn Walker cowered in fear as she waited to hear her dad’s footsteps on the landing at night. Norman Yeo first abused her in her bedroom when she was eight. He started off by showing her pictures of naked women in a porn magazine and telling her she “would be like that soon”. The paedophile moved on to touching and raping her. He carried on until Caryn was  – but more than two decades went by before he was finally brought to justice. Caryn only plucked up the courage to tell police after her older sister Jenny died suddenly aged just  without seeing their vile dad caged for his crimes. Yeo was eventually jailed for  years and Caryn has told the sisters’ horric story in a heartbreaking memoir entitled Tell Me You’re Sorry, Daddy.  She said: “Our childhoods were just awful but the sad thing is, I thought the way we lived was normal. “No one ever told me they loved me, or read me a bedtime story. I was in my twenties before anyone gave me a hug. “I hated every second of what my dad did to me. I was so little and it was so painful but he lied and told me all dads did this to their daughters. “I never thought I’d find the courage to go to the police. I assumed these shyterrible things must somehow be my fault. I’m speaking out for Jenny. “She always said she wanted to write a book about what happened to us but now it’s up to me.”  Jenny had been taken into care aged  months after social workers found her severely underweight and covered in bruises. The authorities suspected Yeo and his we Lesley of harming Jenny – but, amazingly, left Caryn in their clutches in Wallasey, Merseyside – a decision she questions every day. Caryn said: “Why didn’t they take me, too  They obviously knew my parents were not nice people. “We lived in complete fear of upsetting them. I don’t have any happy memories of my childhood. “I only realised this wasn’t normal when I went to a friend’s house after school and her family were smiling and laughing together and her mum was baking cakes. “Her house felt so safe, but we were never safe. We were always on edge.” Caryn was eight when Yeo first crept into her room in the dead of night. She said: “It wasn’t long before he started trying to rape me. Eventually, he succeeded. It would happen night after night, but there was nothing I could do.  “I would just lie on my bed, covered in blood, praying for it to stop. “I tried to barricade my door to stop him from getting into my room but he always found a way.” The sexual abuse only ended when Yeo left the family home, shortly after Caryn turned , but the mental scars remained. Aged , she fell pregnant with her only son Karl, now , to an older boyfriend. She said: “I’d never felt love like I felt for my baby, as I held his hand in his little glass cot. I whispered, ‘I don’t know how to love you, but I am going to learn’. “I was so nervous, as no one had ever shown me any love, but I was determined to protect him. Yet it made me so sad that no one had felt that way about me when I was a baby.” As adults, she and Jenny tried to forge the sisterly bond they’d missed out on as children. Jenny had spent her childhood being shunted between foster carers and children’s homes, only shyseeing Caryn when she was allowed home for visits. Caryn said: “We got on well but we didn’t have that natural connection that sisters who have been brought up together have.  “It was painful for us to talk about what had happened. Jenny told me that when she’d got her first flat, aged , Dad would come round constantly, demanding sex. “To him, his daughters were just something to be used.” The sisters had finally become close when Jenny died of a brain aneurysm aged . Caryn said: “My mum called to tell me but there was no emotion in her voice. I was distraught.” For the next four years, Caryn lived in limbo, scared she couldn’t find the strength to report her dad. But a chance meeting with him in  at her gran’s nursing home spurred her into action. She said: “I hadn’t seen him for years but I suddenly became paralysed by fear that he might have access to kids. “I drove to the police station three times before I plucked up the courage to go in. They took me straight into a private room and I gave a -page statement.  “It was surreal but I spoke to Jenny in my head a lot, asking her to help me through. “Dad was arrested and tried to kill himself. “But he wouldn’t admit everything he’d done to me so I was told I’d have to give evidence against him in court.” Caryn suffered months of nightmares and flashbacks but refused to back down – convinced Jenny was looking down on her. She said: “Throughout the process, I kept seeing magpies everywhere and I became convinced it was Jenny’s way of telling me she was with me. “The day I took the stand, there was one just outside my house. I really feel like she was with me.” Yeo, then , was found guilty by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court of eight shyoffences of rape and five of indecent assault. He had admitted  charges of indecent assault. Jailing him for  years, Judge John Phipps said: “This case concerns regular, repeated systematic abuse.” Caryn, who went to court to see her dad sentenced in , said: “It was so important for me to hear that, to have someone say it wasn’t my fault.” Yeo is eligible for parole next summer. But Caryn said: “For me, forgiveness is a strange word. I don’t believe what my dad did was OK, but I have been able to let go. “I’m not angry any more because my anger will only hurt me. I’m just glad I’ve finally been able to give Jenny the voice she never had. “I wish she could see how much I’ve grown. I’m no longer a scared little girl. I’m speaking out for both of us.”Tell Me You’re Sorry, Daddy, by Caryn Walker with Linda Watson-Brown, is out now, published by John Blake at pound..

title: british sailor lewis bennett to
story: NewsBritish sailor to admit to killing his new we who vanished on honeymoonLewis Bennett, , had denied killing Isabella Hellmann, whose body has never been found despite a huge search in the waters of the Caribbean, off CubaShareByGreg Woodfield:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEstate agent Isabella Hellmann went missing in May last year"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Brit sailor is expected to admit the manslaughter of his Colombian we, who vanished when their boat sank on a shyhoneymoon voyage. Lewis Bennett, , had denied killing Isabella Hellmann, whose body has never been found despite a huge search in the waters of the Caribbean, off Cuba. But the mining engineer – who lived with his we and their two-year-old daughter in Delray Beach, Florida – is now expected to admit involuntary manslaughter. It is understood he has agreed a plea deal that will avoid him going on trial next month for second degree murder. If it goes ahead he would face a maximum eight years in a federal prison.  Prosecutors alleged that Bennett killed Isabella, , then sank their ft catamaran to inherit her estate. Court papers revealed they had fought over finances and the way daughter Emelia was being raised. Texts from Isabella were revealed – in one she wrote: “You make me crazy shouting, yelling and swearing.” The new charge says Bennett, from Poole, Dorset, killed Isabella “without malice”. Assistant US Attorney Randy Katz confirmed: “Hearing is schedule for the plea change on Monday.” Estate agent Isabella vanished in May last year. Bennett claimed she was at the helm as he slept, but he was jolted awake to find the boat badly damaged and no sign of her. He was later rescued from a le raft by coastguards with pound, of stolen gold and silver coins. He is serving seven months for smuggling. story: NewsColliery brass band records album with songs of peace to be sent to world leadersEXCLUSIVE: The Desford Colliery Brass Band hope Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong Un, Donald Trump and Theresa May will listen to Where Have All the Flowers Gone  and take their message on boardShareCommentsByAntonia Paget:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video behind-scenes-desford-colliery-band-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn Remembrance Sunday – exactly  years after the guns stopped on the Western Front – the nation will fall silent to honour , British heroes who died during World War . But one group will use music to remember the dead too – including members of their own band who laid down their instruments then their lives in the bloody conflict. The Desford Colliery Brass Band has recorded an album filled with tunes of peace which will be sent to every world leader in a bid to spread the message in turbulent times. As war rages in Syria and conflicts continue around the world the musicians hope Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un, Donald Trump and Theresa May will listen to Where Have All the Flowers Gone  and take their message on board. “It was supposed to be the war that ended all wars,” says the band’s shypercussionist Gareth Hand, . “But it didn’t in a lot of places.” “We’re passionate about shyremembering the Armistice but with so much trouble, wars and arguments happening around the world we thought it would be nice to use music to bring unity.  “So not only making sure we shyremember why those people fought for us so long ago, but also creating a legacy of keeping peace moving forward.” Founded in  as the Ibstock United Silver Prize band, the brass band was made up of miners and workmen who spent their days labouring in the colliery pits of Leicestershire. “The villages here were connected very closely with the pits – there was a mine shaft in every other village,” explains Peter Smith, , shychairman of the Desford Colliery Brass Band. “In order for the miners – who had a very hard le – to be able to express themselves they formed brass bands and that’s where colliery mining bands started. “Each village had it’s own little group and it became part of the local tradition. “The bands were essential to the community.”  In , when war broke out with Germany, the Ibstock band was forced to close after  years. As more and more of its members went to fight in the trenches there were too few to attend practices. As news of growing casualties reached Leicestershire from the Western Front, all their families and loved ones could do was wait and hope they would . It is not known exactly how many members of the brass band were lost in the war but casualties among the small group were shybelieved tto have been high. And today Leicestershire has hundreds of war memorials – testament to the huge shynumber of East Midlanders whose generation gave their lives for their country. Those musicians who were not wiped out on the battlefields of France and Belgium found solace in making music together when they finally ed.  The silver band reformed and in the s became Desford Colliery Brass Band – taking the name of the biggest colliery in the area, where many of its members worked. Today the band – based in Coalville, Leics – is going string. Their collection of brass band championship titles is vast – and includes World and European titles They also featured on fly on the wall TV series The Real Brassed Off. The band has played concerts in Russia, Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore and Japan – so their global outlook should be no surprise Peter, who first joined a colliery band aged six, explains: “We wanted to strike a note for peace in these troubled times.On a very local level, lessons of peace can learned from colliery bands across the UK. “We celebrate the power of music and the capacity of the human spirit to inspire communities to triumph against all the odds. Music more than any other medium has ability to promote international peace and shyemotional health and we hope our album can be seen as a celebration of unity and hope.” Gareth, who works as a secondary school PE teacher when he is not volunteering for the band, adds: “Colliery bands are steeped in tradition. “The whole history of coal mining is all about camaraderie.  “For people working down the pit it was a fraternity of friendship and teamwork. “And that’s something that brass banding still does today.” More than .million people have died serving their country since  – from the generations of young men and women wiped out in two world wars, to those who lost their lives during campaigns in Korea, Falklands, Iraq and Afghanistan. Millions will fall silent to remember them next Sunday on November  at am – the moment the armistice was signed between the Allies and Germany  years ago. But for the members of the Desford band the centenary is will be a poignant reminder of a war that ripped their community and band to shreds. But the spirit of renewal endures – and that is something the band wanted to capture in their album.

title: grenfell tower support worker sent
story: NewsGrenfell Tower: Support worker sent to help families quits after affair with mournerEXCLUSIVE The employee has quit over a two-month relationship with the vulnerable woman, who became pregnant.ShareCommentsByNicola Small:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsGrenfell Tower during last years tragedy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRevelations that a support worker had an affair with a Grenfell Tower mourner have been slammed as yet another failing by a creaking Tory council. The employee has quit over a two-month relationship with the vulnerable woman, who became pregnant. She had sought support at a community centre run by Kensington and Cha Borough Council in the wake of the fire which claimed  lives last year. Sources claim he charmed the woman – who lost friends in the fire – before taking advantage of her.  Tonight there were calls for an inquiry and local Labour MP Emma Dent Coad said heads should roll. She told the Sunday Mirror: “This is really awful. I am absolutely horried. It is yet another failure of a failing council. “Who is monitoring what’s going on there  It is an absolute disaster. “If they can’t keep people safe from their own employees – people who have come for help – they are really not doing a good job and need to step down.”  The woman had attended The Curve Community Centre for support in the wake of the fire in North Kensington, West London. It is claimed she fell pregnant and then had an abortion after the support worker told her she would no longer be welcome at the centre. She is said to have ended the affair last month after discovering he was seeing someone  at the same time. The worker was summoned to a meeting after bosses at The Curve found out about the affair. He no longer works for the council. A spokesman for the authority said last night: “We are aware of an issue and it has been dealt with.” He said all staff at The Curve were banned from having relationships with people they were helping and it was “a sackable offence”. In this case the employee resigned. But the authority had not received a formal complaint. The case is the latest appalling betrayal of Grenfell’s grief-stricken community. The Curve claims to be a “safe and welcoming space for families and iniduals” that aims to “provide support in a way that puts you first”.  Services include counselling and housing advice, with activities also on offer such as dance classes, art workshops and movie nights. A wide range of health services are available, ranging from NHS talking therapies to free massages. But this is not the first time the centre – which opened in July  – has been hit by safeguarding issues. Ms Dent Coad said: “There have been concerns. I visited quite a few times in the early months and somebody told me none of the volunteers had been DBS-checked. “I found that really alarming. There seems to be very little scrutiny of what goes on there. It is absolutely appalling.” The council said permanent staff do undergo DBS checks and there are no longer any volunteers working at The Curve. The MP wants to see the council stripped of its role in leading the official Grenfell Response Team.  She said: “It is chaotic. The council does not know what they are doing.All the time they want to cover their butt and that’s why a lot of residents, and me, are angry. They should just admit, we messed up and we need to fix it.” Local councillor Judith Blakeman has written to the council demanding an investigation. She said: “A user of the Curve contacted me to say he was aware of sexual impropriety. “It is meant to be a place of refuge for the local community and something like this is extremely worrying.” Failure to help survivors swtly led to the resignation of four council bigwigs. A public inquiry, which has heard harrowing accounts of the tragedy, resumes next week.

story: NewsHow Meghan Markle used £, Down Under royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionsThe Duchess of Sussexs carefully picked clothing symbolised a lot of her beliefs and causes she strongly supportsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video duchess-sussex-didnt-simply-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle used her royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionate beliefs, it has been claimed. The mum-to-be impressed fashion-lovers with her incredible looks - covering everything from comfy casual to red carpet glam from high street names, as well as designer brands. And communication coach Robin Kermode believes the pregnant duchess, , used her strategically picked attire to signal her strongly held beliefs. In total, it is estimated Meghans Down Under tour wardrobe cost pound,. The items of clothing with signicant meanings behind them include her pumps created out of recycled plastic water bottles, and jeans made by female victims of human trafficking and sexual exploitation. With the world of the eyes upon her, some of Meghans outfits have unsurprisingly sold out as fans rush to snap them up. The jeans made by female victims of sexual exploitation  On several occasions during the overseas tour, Meghan opted to wear jeans from Outland - including the Harriet pair, pictured above. The Australian brand was founded by James Bartle after he saw first-hand how human traffickers prey on vulnerable young girls in order to service the sex industry. Determined to making a change, James learnt that once a girl has been rescued and supported through her recovery, a sustainable career path is vital for securing her future. He created the Denim Project, to enable those girls who demonstrated an interest in sewing to put their new skills to use. Outlands team of seamstresses offer positions to those at risk of falling into poverty, and has broadened its mission to set a standard for the treatment and remuneration of young female workers in the garment manufacturing industry. It also sources ethically and environmentally sound raw materials, from organic cotton pocket linings to recycled packaging. After the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their engagement, they asked people who wanted to mark the occasion to donate to charities they had picked instead of giving them wedding gts. One of these charities included the Myna Mahila Foundation, which empowers women in Mumbai’s urban slums, by providing them with a trusted network, where they are supported professionally and personally to help them grow as iniduals and businesswomen. Thus Meghans Outland jeans reflect her desire to help vulnerable women which she has spoken so openly about. The vegan leather trainers  Meghan went comfy and casual as she donned white Veja V trainers while on a boat trip in Sydney during the Invictus Games. The trainers got everyone talking as they are environmentally friendly, and made from raw materials sourced from organic farming and ecological agriculture. Some of the shoes also use recycled plastic bottles and many have soles made from wild Amazonian rubber. The French fashion brands founders, Seacutebastien Kopp and Franccedilois-Ghislain Morillion visited clothing and food factories in South America, Asia and Australia while running a nonprofit group — and were appalled by what they saw. So in , they founded Veja in France with the vision of making trainers using the most ecological materials and ethical suppliers they could find. Fashion fans were delighted when they saw Meghan wearing a pair and the duchess is keen on environmental and conservation causes. The recycled plastic bottle pumps  Meghan wore Rothys flats twice on tour, including during a beach clean-up in Melbourne. The pumps are made from recycled plastic water bottles that would otherwise have been destined for landfill - and have been dubbed the most politically correct shoes on the planet by Vogue. The insoles on all of Rothy’s shoes contain recycled foam the rubber soles are made without environmentally stressful black carbon. The yarn comes from plastic and even the packaging’s made from post-consumer recycled materials. Meghan supports charity Surfers Against Sewage, which is a national marine conservation and campaigning charity. It inspires, unites and empowers communities to take action to protect oceans, beaches, waves and wildle. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the charity said: Our work as a national marine conservation charity empowers tens of thousands of volunteers annually to protect beaches for everyone. We are currently focused on tackling plastic pollution and this support will help us move towards our vision of Plastic Free Coastlines.” So it is very fitting Meghan wore the pumps during the beach visit - signalling her passion to protecting the sea from plastic. The sustainable brand  The Duchess of Sussex wore a stunning custom-made silk wool cocktail dress in dark navy by Gabriela Hearst at Government House in Wellington. The sustainable luxury brand is based on a less is more approach. Gabriela is a notable feminist designer and political activist. She wanted to create a brand that reflects a slower pace and process: where things are made with care and detail, where tradition is more important than trend, where there is a purpose to every piece, according to her website. She takes into consideration where materials come from and who is making them. Meghan wore the dress to deliver a speech to honor the th anniversary of female suffrage. The empowering dress  Meghan looked sensational when she wore a beautul white Theia dress for dinner with the King and Queen of Tonga. The label is inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, who had an incredible power to turn everything that she gazed on to light. The Theia dresses are designed to make women feel confident – similar to Meghan’s beliefs. The website explains about their collection: Inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, this evening wear, bridal and day dress collection was created to bring out every womans inner goddess. One of the original Titans, Theia, who ruled during the Greek Golden Age, possessed the incredible power of light which radiated from her sparkling eyes. All that she gazed upon glittered, becoming luminous and radiant. She imbued gold and silver with their shine. She gave diamonds their fire and rubies and emeralds their sparkle. Her three children Helios the sun, Celene the moon, and Eos the dawn, all continue to bring light in to the world everyday. The woman who wears Theia will be filled with confidence knowing her dress fits wonderfully and looks beautul on her, thus naturally allowing her inner goddess to shine. title: kate winslet hailed family mum
story: NewsKate Winslet hailed by family of a mum who died of cancer after visiting her bedside in her final daysEXCLUSIVE The Oscar winner made a string of emotional visits to Gemma Nuttall at a hospice, giving her strength as she neared the end of her courageous battleShareCommentsByMatthew BarbourVikki White:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe actress Kate Winslet leaves the crematorium with her husband Edward Smith after the funeral service "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHollywood star Kate Winslet has been hailed as “an amazing human being” as the family of a mum who died of cancer told how the actress was by her bedside in her final days. The Oscar winner made a string of emotional visits to Gemma Nuttall, giving her strength as she neared the end of her brave battle. Kate – who spoke at -year-old Gemma’s funeral on Tuesday – also gave her unlikely pal a precious bracelet as an heirloom for the daughter whose le Gemma had put before her own. And she made a vow to keep raising money to fight cancer in her memory. The two became pals when the star read about Gemma’s plight shortly after losing her own mum to the disease in .  Kate, , and Titanic co-star Leonardo DiCaprio raised hundreds of thousands towards Gemma’s last-ditch immunotherapy treatment at a German clinic in a bid to win a five-year battle against oian cancer. Gemma’s mum Helen Sproates said: “Kate really supported my daughter and helped her. Whenever Gemma was down she’d text her and bolster her up. She’s very strong – and we needed that strength. “Kate lost her own mum to liver cancer, so for her to put that on the back burner and support us must have been really hard as she’s still grieving herself.  “I know she found it hard, but she did it anyway. That’s an amazing human being who can do something like that.” At the funeral, Kate wore a pink scarf in honour of the new Gemma Rose Foundation set up to help her friend – Rose being the character she played in Titanic. In tears, the star told mourners at Accrington Crematorium, Lancs, courageous Gemma “was clearly a fighter”.  Gemma had been  weeks pregnant when she was diagnosed in . But she turned down a termination and delayed crucial le-saving treatment so she could give birth to Penelope, now four. Kate said: “Her extraordinary determination to beat her cancer for Penelope was something that deeply moved me and made me want to help.” She and Leonardo, , auctioned off three “Jack and Rose” date nights to raise the money to complete the pound,-a-time course of immunotherapy. It was Gemma’s last chance and she seemed to be beating the disease – but her cancer ed this summer and she died on October . Helen, , said: “Kate’s visited her regularly. I messaged her when we were moving to the hospice and said: ‘You need to come one more timeyou want to see her, we don’t know how long she’s got’. “She came up the next day. It meant a lot to me because it meant a lot to Gemma. “I didn’t intrude on their last visit but I know they talked a lot about their Foundation and Kate got Gemma a gt which she’s left to be passed onto Penelope. It’s a bracelet. “She’s got Penelope’s name engraved on it.”  Play centre boss Helen told how Kate had become part of their family throughout their ordeal, and was just “Kate” to them, rather than a Hollywood star. “The thing with Kate is she’s absolutely lovely, she’s very grounded and down-to-earth, very warm,” said Helen. “Her and Gemma really clicked. We’d sit on the bed, the three of us, eating popcorn and watching TV.” She told how Gemma had been cancer-free for nine months after her treatment in Germany – but this summer, she began to suffer from bad back pain. “She had been having no symptoms and we were all beginning to think she was actually cured,” said Helen. “She had an MRI scan at Blackburn Royal and we could tell straight away. The doctor was really upset so before he even told us anything so we knew. “Gemma had three tumours in her spine and two brain tumours. We were devastated.”  Her care became palliative, but she still refused to give in. “Because she was so young, her way of fighting this was to not give up,” said Helen. “She realised talking about Penelope’s plans and her funeral was her admitting defeat. “She was asked to sign a Do Not Resuscitate form a month before she passed away and she wouldn’t. She just said: ‘If I sign that I’m giving up on my daughter’. “It was really hard as a family because I needed to know things for Penelope’s future but she just couldn’t face talking about it and I wasn’t about to push her.” “I see so much of Gemma in Penelope - they look alike and have the same mannerisms and sense of humour. It makes me smile because it’s like raising Gemma all over again.” Helen cared for Gemma at home in Haslingden, Lancs, until nine days before she died. By the time she went into Pendleside Hospice, she was paralysed below her chest and blind in one eye. “To watch her decline was horrible,” said Helen. “She ended up weighing about four stone. But she insisted on being at home with Penelope and looking after her. She carried on like a Trojan.” “On Kate’s last visit we managed to get Gemma’s wishes for the Foundation out of her,” said Helen. “She wanted to help young parents with cancer like we’ve been helped.  “We’re hoping the Foundation’s going to be as big as Marie Curie, butwe can save just one le it’s worth everything. I would just urge everyone to get checked out early in the fight against cancer. It might save your le.” She said Gemma “didn’t have a nice death. She didn’t fall asleep peacefully. And we didn’t do goodbyes – in Gemma’s world there wasn’t a goodbye.” Penelope, now being looked after by dad Alex and both sets of parents, vvisited her mum in the hospice. Helen said: “We’re still going through the process of explaining to her what has happened. How do you do that with a four-year-old ” Although Gemma didn’t want to discuss death, she did design a memory box for her daughter. “Everything’s going in that box – all the comments on Facebook, the cards, the press cuttings,” said Helen. And on Penelope’s wrist one day, there’ll be a bracelet. Given by a Hollywood star to her courageous mum.To donate to the Gemma Rose Foundation, visit uk.gofundme teamgemma

title: lego masters teen rare bone
story: NewsLego Masters: Teen with rare bone disorder to tell story of battle by building hospital ward on TV showLewis Bird uses the toy blocks to tell the story of his battle with degenerative Morquio SyndromeShareCommentsByMirror:,  NOV NewsMorquio syndrome sufferer Lewis Bird builds amazing Lego creations "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRare bone disorder sufferer Lewis Bird will soon be on TV rebuilding his le – with Lego. The teenager uses the toy blocks to tell the story of his battle with degenerative Morquio syndrome – a harrowing condition believed to affect just  people in Britain. His passion for clicking together amazing creations won him a place on Channel ’s new series of Lego Masters. And Lewis, , couldn’t wait to get started as his parents and older brother Jack,  – who also has the condition – watched with pride. “Lego is an obsession of mine,” he says. “I love the creative aspect of it.”  Viewers will see eight teams of two compete against each other as they are set challenges to build awe-inspiring creations. Lewis, teamed with dad Paul, is tasked with creating a miniature world in a tower block. So he builds a hospital modelled on the specialist baby care unit in Leeds where he spent much of his childhood. It features a caterpillar on the wall, a memory from their time in the hospital, and a small Lego character with a burned hand, modelled on Jack. The disorder caused both the boys’ spines to stop growing as children, while their limbs continued to develop. There is no cure.  Paul, , says: “As our children grew, we got used to using wheelchairs – but their friends fell by their wayside. They didn’t get invited to other kids’ houses because no one had wheelchair access. Lego has been a constant throughout Lewis’s le. In the show it was an opportunity to reflect on our le. A kind of welcome to our world.” Paul, a British Legion handyman, and we Julie first realised something was badly wrong with Jack when he was diagnosed with a “hip click” – a popping sound in his joint – at six weeks old. It was three years before they were given a diagnosis.  “It was a nightmare,” says Paul. “We were even investigated for child neglect because Jack hadn’t put on any weight.” When Jack was three, Julie fell pregnant with Lewis and the family faced the agonising wait to find outhe also suffered from Morquio syndrome. They were initially told he was a carrier but didn’t have the disease – then he developed the same symptoms as his brother. “The only family we could find with two children with the syndrome at that time was in Canada – that’s how rare it was,” says Paul. “Our world fell apart. I have no idea what age they will live to. The oldest person is in her mid-s at the moment.” But the devastating diagnosis has not held Lewis back – and he hopes one day to work for Lego. “That would be his dream,” said Paul.Lego Masters s to Channel  on Tuesday at pm

story: NewsMan, , lay dying on roof for three days after climbing up to fix aerialRon Easton, from Bigbury-on-Sea, Devon, is believed to have climbed up a ladder to fix his aerial when he got stuck in a gulleyShareCommentsByKarl GraftonJamie Hawkins:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video local-man--who-trapped-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old man died after becoming trapped on his roof trying to fix his broken aerial. Ron Easton was found in a gulley on his flat roof at Bigbury-on-Sea in Devon on  October after his neighbour became worried at a build up of milk bottles and newspapers. It is believed that he climbed onto the house extension using a ladder. The pensioner, known locally as Ton-Up Ron after his love of cars, was stuck on his roof for three days before emergency services were alerted. A  call describing the moment he was found on the roof still breathing has also been released.  He was airlted to Derrord Hospital in Plymouth but died on Friday, his family said. Louise Wainwright, editor of newsletter Bigbury News, said the incident had raised questions about community and checking on neighbours. Ron was a very private man... its very sad, she said.  Hazel Osborne, who watched the rescue operation told PlymouthLive : Hes an incredible old boy who still drives his MG sports car. He was a rally driver who once drove in the Dakar rally. It was her friend who raised the alarm, she said: The fire service and ambulance were here. There were paramedics and first responders and then the Devon Air Ambulance arrived and you could see clouds of dust.  A spokesperson for Devon  Somerset Fire Service told PlymouthLive: He appears to have climbed on to his house extension on a ladder. We sent three appliances and an aerial ladder  to the scene. The space to work in was far too narrow for our aerial , so firefighters used a stretcher from ambulance to climb up onto the roof and rescue him. Villagers paid tribute to the pensioner and lowered their flag to half mast as a mark of respect.

story: NewsMum-of-three who paid £, to dating agency which failed to find her boyfriend "no longer has dreams"Tereza Burki, , won a court case earlier this year after she claimed "exclusive" agency Seventy Thirty had misled herShareCommentsByJames BrewsterDave Burke:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video upmarket-dating-agency-seven-thirty-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA orced mum-of-three who paid pound, to an exclusive dating agency which failed to find the man of her dreams says she no longer has dreams. Tereza Burki, , earlier this year won a court case when a judge ruled she had been misled, and was given her money back. But she said the case has given her little satisfaction. She had hoped to find a fulfilling relationship and possibly a fourth child, but Seventy Thirty Ltd failed to deliver. Describing her experience to the Daily Mail , she said: I’m finding it hard right now.  I no longer have dreams. I used to dream of meeting someone, of having a future, when I went to these people. She told the newspaper that material things dont matter so much now, and she fears her child-bearing years are behind her. Ms Burki, a private wealth consultant, said she wanted to believe the Cinderella story when she signed up with the agency. The agency was unable to find her the man of her dreams and possibly the father of her child, she told the High Court. She said the agency assured her it only dealt in creme de la creme matches and could introduce her to bachelors you dream of meeting. When she signed up with the agency in , Ms Burkis requirements for the men she wanted to meet were not modest, Judge Richard Parkes QC said.  She wanted a wealthy man with a lestyle similar or more affluent than her own and, ideally, multiple residences. But the most important factor for Ms Burki, who lives in Cha, where homes sell for millions, was that her soulmate would be prepared to have more children, as she wanted four. But today Mr Parkes ordered the agency to repay her fee, ruling that she had been deceived by Seventy Thirtys then managing director. He told the court: Gertrude Stein quipped that whoever said money cant buy happiness didnt know where to shop. This case is about a woman looking for romantic happiness who says she was tricked into shopping in the wrong place, paying a large sum to a dating which, she says, made promises but failed to produce the goods.  Upholding Ms Burkis claim , he ruled the agencys then managing director, Lemarc Thomas, guilty of deceit in misleading her. Although the agency boasted of more than , members, the truth was that only about  of them were men actively looking for love, he said. And the management consultant would never have paid her money and joined up had Mr Thomas not knowingly given her a wholly  impression. Agency founder, Susie Ambrose, said Seventy Thirty had successfully matched over , lonely hearts and  babies had been born since she set it up in . But the judge said Mr Thomas had told Ms Burki that there were a substantial number of wealthy men on the agencys books, actively looking for matches. She had no means of checking the truth of what he told her, and no reason to doubt it, he added. And she relied on Mr Thomass word before spending a large amount of money on a dating agency in the hope of finding a partner who would give her a fourth child. The Knightsbridge-based agency claimed to have about , active members and that Ms Burki had been sent five potential matches that fit her requirements soon after joining. But the judge said: My conclusion from the evidence is that there are at the very most perhaps  active members of Seventy Thirty, and probably fewer. That points to a maximum of around  active male members. A membership of  active men cannot by any stretch of the imagination be described as a substantial number, he continued. The representations made by Mr Thomas were therefore  and misleading. The judge accepted that the agency did have a sizeable database and was not a fundamentally dishonest or fraudulent operation. He emphasised that he had not found that it was not an effective matchmaking agency or that it did not in the event provide Ms Burki with suitable matches. And, had Mr Thomas told her the truth, Ms Burki would have had little cause for complaint. But he added: What I have found is that Mr Thomas ly represented the size of the active membership of Seventy Thirty to Ms Burki and induced her to pay a substantial fee on the strength of his deceit. Had Ms Burki known what the true size of the active membership was, she would not have joined Seventy Thirty. Worried about running out of time to have another child, she felt very let down and disappointed by the fact that Mr Thomass claims for the service turned out to be untrue. And, as well as giving her her money back, the judge awarded her pound for the disappointment and sadness she suffered. Her total award came to pound,. Against that, Ms Burki was ordered to pay Seventy Thirty pound, in libel damages after writing a damning Google review of the agency, describing it as a scam. Ms Burki has not proved that Seventy Thirty lacked the means or intention to operate an effective match making service, let alone that it was engaged in a fraudulent scheme to extract money from its clients for the benefit of its founder the judge ruled. Giving evidence during the case, Miss Burki told the judge: You shouldnt promise people who are in a fragile state of mind, in their mid-s, the man of their dreams. You are entrusting a service you believe is professional, who will take care of your interests and have your best interests at heart.

title: retirees tricked supplying parts irans
story: NewsRetirees tricked into supplying parts for Iran’s nuclear programme from British terrace homeEXCLUSIVE: All that pensioners Paul Attwater and Iris wanted was some extra cash to pay for a Crawley Town FC season ticket and a few holidays in the sunShareCommentsByDan Warburton:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPaul Attwater and Iris were hauled into court over the issue "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA retired couple today reveal how they were tricked into shysupplying parts for Iran’s nuclear programme from their terrace home in Britain. All that pensioners Paul Attwater and Iris wanted was some extra cash to pay for a Crawley Town FC season ticket and a few holidays in the sun. But shocked Paul, , and Iris, , were hauled into court after being accused of helping a rogue state develop weapons of mass destruction. Far from being sophisticated arms shydealers, the grandparents were selling nuts and bolts to an Iraqi-born businessman in Malaysia. Instead of engaging in espionage, they were counting screws on the living room floor of their pound, end of terrace and storing aircraft parts in their attic.  They were stunned when investigators told them the hardware was being shipped on to Iran where it could be used by the rogue nation in a nuclear weapons shydevelopment programme. A judge spared them jail this week after saying they were “very, very naive” and had been deceived by the businessman. But the couple – despite losing pound, in the business venture and being owed pound, – fear they will lose their home as prosecutors aim to seize their assets under the Proceeds of Crime Act. Former secretary Iris said: “It’s been an absolute nightmare. We’ve been made out to be international arms dealers but nothing could be further from the truth. “It’s nothing like they were saying – it wasn’t weapons. We were literally counting , nuts and bolts on the living room floor.” Iris, who along with Paul are diehard fans of League Two side Crawley Town, added: “We were just wanting to make a bit of money to pay for the football and go on holiday.  “Now I’m petried that I might lose my house. The whole thing has made me ill.” The couple were duped by businessman Alexander George, , and were unaware he was using a complex network of companies in the Far East and a Dutch shipping firm to send the parts on to Iran. Iris said: “We were friends with Alex. He would always be overly friendly and tell us we were like family. “We would meet up for drinks and shydinner and pay for everything, we just thought he was a kind person. “But we haven’t spoken to him since this happened, we had no idea what he was doing. He’s a very good liar. “We’ll never have anything to do with him again. We are absolutely gutted. Our whole reputations have been ruined.” Paul, who has  grandchildren, told the Sunday People: “When we were interviewed and they told me the parts could have been going to Iran, I thought it was a joke. I had no idea whatsoever that these parts were going there. I didn’t even believe they were for military use. ” Paul and Iris ran a little company called Pairs Aviation from their pound, home in the Bewbush neighbourhood of Crawley, West Sussex.  Their dining room table was strewn with paperwork as they transformed the five-bedroom home into a makesht office. Prosecutors said the couple were warned in  that the parts they were sending to Malaysia required a licence. But Paul and Iris, who now live in Telford, Shrops, say a Dutch shipping firm told them they could continue to send the supplies. And they say they told Customs officials exactly what they were doing during an audit in . Iris said: “We’ve never tried to hide anything. “Paul is as straight as anything. He’s completely black and white, he’s just not like that. He would not have done something wrong intentionally. I trust him explicitly. “This has ruined our lives. Our friends and shyfamily know we’re not the people we’ve been made out to be. But it’s been hard. “It’s not like we were making vast sums of money. In the last two years we lost pound, each year. “We made decent money on paper but it all went back on paying for parts.  “And some of the companies abroad still owe us in excess of , dollars.” Paul pleaded guilty at London’s Southwark Crown Court to being shyknowingly concerned in the exportation of goods with intent to evade shyprohibition or restriction. He agreed to sign a basis of plea before his shyformal guilty plea, in which he said: “I did not know or believe that goods or aircraft components would be shipped to Iran.” Iris denied the same charge but was convicted by a jury. They were both given a six-month suspended jail sentence and barred from being company directors for six years. Judge Michael Grieve QC said: “The fact that you were, in effect, groomed by Mr George I accept. “He deceived you. I do not for one moment think either of you are bad people. You have, in my view, been very, very naive.” The couple’s barrister, George Hepburne-Scott, said: “These two very decent honourable people were groomed and deceived by a sophisticated offender with a global web of companies. “They now have a criminal conviction and are facing losing their house. They completely trusted this man and they were totally duped by him.” George, of Bristol, was found guilty of being knowingly shyconcerned in the supply or delivery of controlled goods to an embargoed destination. He will be sentenced next month.

title: saira khan forgiveness always triumph
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Why forgiveness will always triumph over hatredEverywhere you look people are spouting vitriol at one another for their faith, their gender, their ­sexuality, even their food choices!ShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  NOV NewsopinionSaira Khan and Laura Pradelska"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHow is it that in a world so full of hate, the very shyiniduals who might be forgiven for embracing it are so often shining examples of tolerance and understanding  Everywhere you look people are spouting vitriol at one another for their faith, their gender, their shysexuality, even their food choices! And all it does is stoke the fires of enmity and raise the emotional temperature until you end up with a white supremacist gunning down  elderly Jewish people in a synagogue or a police investigation into alleged anti-Semitic social media posts by Labour Party members. So when I was asked to host this week’s  Winter Gala by shyQuilliam, the anti-extremism think tank, I knew it was going to be a worthwhile and important evening. As the Moslem child of Pakistani immigrant parents, I felt it was my duty to do my bit, as did my lovely co-host, the Jewish Game of Thrones actress Laura Pradelska, whose grandparents survived the Holocaust. What I hadn’t expected was quite how heart-warming it would be.  Because what we witnessed from the people we honoured that night was the opposite of hatred – it was courage, understanding and kindness against all the odds. The two people I can’t get out of my head – or my heart – were -year-old Ahmad Nawaz and -year old Mindu Hornick.When Ahmad was just  years old Taliban terrorists attacked his school in the Pakistani city of Peshawar. His little brother and  other children were gunned down. Ahmad was shot himself and only survived by playing dead. He was flown to Birmingham for surgery that saved his arm from amputation, and now he tours schools in the West Midlands, telling his story to pupils at risk of radicalisation. When Mindu was  she was sent to Auschwitz concentration camp.She and her sister escaped the gas chamber by pretending to be older, and claiming they were skilled tailors.The rest of her family died.  Now she too tours schools telling her story as a living warning of the dangers of prejudice and extremism. As I listened to these two extraordinary human beings, I thought thatanyone had the right to hate, it would be them.The trauma and loss they both suffered is beyond imagining.But there they were, side by side, the young Muslim lad and the elderly Jewish death camp survivor, working together to promote inter-faith relations andto help survivors of violent extremism in the UK. And these are the voices we need to listen to.The extremists may have used social media to ide communities and spread their evil rhetoric, but while people like Ahmad and Mindu endure, their message of respect gives us cause to hope. We should all listen to them, and reject the easy stereotypes peddled by the fear-mongers. If human nature were about focusing on what ides us we’d still be living in caves. I choose to believe that the American Muslims who raised , for the Jewish victims of the Pittsburgh race hate shooting are a much better example. An example we all need to followwe want to turn back this tide of hate.

title: teen yob who pelted vulnerable
story: NewsSnapchat yob who pelted vulnerable woman with flour and eggs says HES now too scared to leave his homeCohan Semple says hes received "death threats from random people" after the sickening attack on mum-of-one Janice Morris in Bury St Edmunds, SuffolkShareByLouis SmithSophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCohan Semple humiliated the vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage yob who humiliated a vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs is now too scared to leave his home, it is reported.Cohan Semple says hes struggling to leave his house amid death threats following the sickening attack on -year-old Janice Morris. The teenager was among five boys who targeted Janice as she sat on a park bench in Suffolk in what a court heard was a despicable attack.An image showing them smiling and pointing at their cowering victim sparked widespread revulsion after being posted on Snapchat and Facebook. Until this week, the boys - all between  and  years old at the time - had had their identities protected because of their age. But Semple turned  last week, meaning he could be unmasked for the first time. Speaking out yesterday, the teenager - who pleaded guilty to threatening behaviour - described how he has received death threats from strangers.He told Sun Online: I’m struggling to leave the house at the moment. Since those pictures have gone on Facebook, I’ve had death threats from random people. Askedhe wanted to apologise for the attack in Bury St Edmunds, he reportedly said he was not ready because of the death threats sent to him online.Semple and his friends faced online abuse and direct threats from people who were sickened by the picture after it was shared online. Yesterday, presiding magistrate Simon Islett told the younger members of the group they could have faced jail termsthey were a few years older. He described the incident as a despicable attack on a vulnerable woman and said it was “terrying” for the mum-of-one.Mr Islett told one boy: “She didn’t know what was going to happen or what the outcome was going to be.  You have got to put yourself in the victim’s place and consider your actions and the effect it might have on them.” Janice was sitting in a park when she was approached by Semple and the group. Ipswich Youth Court heard they began asking questions about drugs before one of the boys spat in her face. Prosecutor Wayne Ablett said: He came from behind the bench and spat at her, with spit landing on her face. She said, What did you do that for  She recalls the boy laughing at her, then spitting at her again. Magistrates heard the group disappeared for around  minutes, then ed with flour bought at a nearby shop. Mr Ablett said: These items were chucked at and thrown at her body, covering her completely in flour. The boys were still laughing. She was spat at again and one of them had taken a photo of her. She heard one of them say, Were filming it.  The boys were arrested after the incriminating photo appeared on Facebook in July this year. Janice suffered no physical injuries but was left severely distressed by her ordeal. Semple, who admitted threatening behaviour, lives in Bury St Edmunds with his mum. The court heard since the incident he had received death threats, and felt remorseful and sorry for what happened. Declan Gallagher, defending Semple, said: He took the photograph and put it on his own Snapchat. One of his circle then took a screenshot of that, then it went onto Facebook, then it went beyond. He was released on bail, to be sentenced at an adult court on December . Four other boys, aged , ,  and , admitted the same offence yesterday and were sentenced to -month referral orders. They were also ordered to pay pound each in compensation to the victim. A sixth defendant, aged , denied using threatening behaviour and will face trial at the youth court on February .

title: tiny miniature detached house once
story: NewsTiny miniature detached house once home to eight goes on the market for £,The minuscule one-up, one-down in Stanton Drew, Somerset is on the market for £,ShareCommentsByMirror:,  NOV NewsThe adorable miniature house in Stanton Drew is on the market for £, "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tiny detached property that once squeezed a family of eight into its rafters is up for sale. The adorable one-up, one-down has a floor plan that reaches the dizzy heights of  square feet. The thatched hexagonal home is a well known landmark in Stanton Drew, a Somerset village about  miles south of Bristol. Originally constructed in , the buildings first le was as a toll house, collecting fees from those heading west towards the coast, The Bristol Post reported.  It is said a money pouch used to hang on a hook over the front door, into which coach drivers would drop their fares as they passed freely along the road. But by , The Round House was already a residential dwelling. Village folk say a family of eight once lived within its small confines, with bunk beds built amid the roof rafters. The exposed beams remain today – but it still takes some imagination to see how eight people once fit. The hexagonal internal accommodation of the Round House includes an open plan kitchen and living area as well a modern shower room on the ground floor.  A narrow twisting staircase leads to a double bedroom which has a vaulted ceiling with exposed beams, and enjoys a lovely countryside aspect. Chapel shaped windows with shutters, an arched entrance door and an out of service post box all add to the charm of the property. While living inside the house may not be for the claustrophobic – step outside and you have all the space you could want. While the actual plot of land is effectively a patch of grass between roads, the unspoilt countryside at the heart of the Chew Valley would be on your doorstep.  The Round House fits well within Stanton Drew, which has a range of listed buildings dating from the th to th centuries as well as a primary school, pub, church and village hall. It is within a comfortable commute of Bristol or Bath, while a school bus runs to the popular Chew Valley Secondary School. The miniature home is on the market for pound,.

story: NewsVet reveals one simple move to stop a dog attack after baby girl mauled to death in front of mumWARNING: DISTRESSING CONTENT Veterinarian Brett Levitzke has spoken out after one-year-old Triniti Harrell was mauled to death by her familys pet pitbullShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video how-stop-dog-attacks-revealed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vet has revealed one simple move that could stop a dog attack after a one-year-old girl was mauled to death by a pitbull in front of her screaming mum. Little Triniti Harrell was playing with her mother, Miranda Harrell, in their front yard when their pet dog suddenly attacked and began thrashing her around. In a harrowing  call, a distraught Miranda, from North Carolina, US, could be heard telling the operator, He wont stop!, and Help me, shes dying! After being instructed to do so by the operator, she then bravely ran inside her home, grabbed a kne and tried to slit the throat of the six-year-old pitbull. But heartbreakingly, she could be heard crying: This kne is too dull.  Triniti died in hospital days after the attack last week, WRAL reports. And in the aftermath of the tragedy, veterinarian Brett Levitzke has revealed one little-known move that could help people stop dog attacks. If you pick them up by the hind legs theyre off balance, their first reaction may be to let go and then turn around, he told Inside Edition. There is no suggestion this action could have saved Trinitis le. Other experts have previously said punching the dog in the nose and the muzzle, distracting it with an item of clothing or an accessory, or using your entire body weight on the animal to break its bones could help in the event of an attack. The horric incident on October  could only be stopped when the pitbull was shot dead by an Edgecombe County deputy - who had to fire at it twice.  This was despite Miranda and the  operators efforts to save Triniti. In a recording of the emergency call, the operator asks Miranda: Can you get hold of anything - a pot, pan, shovel, anything youve got around your house  He then tells her to whack the dog right in the centre of the top of his head. He adds: If you hit him hard enough, youll knock him out. But devastatingly, Miranda yells back: He wont stop! The operator continues: Find something and hit him with it. The mum responds: Im hitting him as hard as I can. She then screams a long cry of desperation: Help me! In a last-ditch bid to save Triniti, the dispatcher instructs Miranda to dash into her home in Rocky Mount and grab a weapon like a steak kne.  After the mother replies that she cant leave her daughter alone, he says: It will take you  seconds to run in the house and grab it. He then adds: I need you to go find a kne immediately. The mother replies: OK. After grabbing a kne, she is then told to slit the bottom of her pets neck. The dispatcher says: Grab him by one ear and cut along the bottom of his neck. Hes going to let go. Its going to release his jaw muscles. He tells Miranda the animal wont have a choice but to let go. However, despite her efforts to cut her dog, the mum finds the blade too dull. As she pleads again for help, the operator tells her he needs her to do anything she can do with the weapon to make the pet let go. The dogs le is not a concern to me at this point, he says.  The recording then comes to an end. Triniti was rushed to hospital after the terrying attack. But despite the efforts of medics at UNC Childrens Hospital in Chapel Hill - and other hospitals - to save her le, she passed away just days later. Edgecombe County Sherf Clee Atkinson confirmed her mother had tried to stab the pitbull before a deputy shot it dead at the scene. Speaking to WRAL News after the tragedy, Miranda said: I did all I could. Sherf Atkinson said: Its just one of those incidents. They were playing, having a good time, and the dog reacted at some point. Triniti - who was laid to rest by her loved ones earlier this week - is not the only person to have fallen victim to a dog attack in recent weeks.  In the West Midlands, a teenage girl was reportedly left with her lip hanging off after being savaged by a dog as she walked home from school. Chloe Lloyd, , is said to have suffered le-changing injuries after she was attacked by the animal on Ellerton Walk, Wolverhampton, last month. Her mother Claire Forrester said there was blood everywhere. The same month, a -year-old man was left in a coma after his genitals were ripped off and eaten by a bulldog named Biggie Smalls. The man, who has not been named, was found lying unconscious inside a flat by emergency crews in Haddington, East Lothian, Scotland. It was later reported he had apparently smeared his crotch in peanut butter. And yesterday, footage emerged showing a pitbull launching an attack on a Siberian husky at a dog show in Chiang Mai, Thailand, leaving it bloodied.

The -year-old girl was brutally murdered after she allegedly refused to have sex with her neighbour - who was of a higher caste to her. The horric attack took place in the Salem district of Tamil Nadu. According to local police, the accused Dinesh Kumar was arrested and charged under the act that criminalises caste-based violence - a law that has existed in the country since . Ponkarthik Kumar, a senior police official in the district, told CNN: The girl was brutally murdered. The investigation is ongoing and the accused has been arrested. In India, Hindus are separated into four main categories - Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and the Shudras.  These are then ided further into around , castes and , sub-castes, each based on their specic occupation. According to reports, the deceased teen had told her mum about the mans continuous sexual advances that she had turned down. The lower castes, also known as Dalits, are often denied the right to education and employment. Despite court rulings to make the law fair for those in lower castes, activists say that deep-rooted bias remains.  Radhika Ganesh, a political activist who has been advocating for Dalit rights told CNN: Why does the establishment not show that strength  Such incidents are constantly happening.
